item.description: Knowledge is supreme in human life, Poojya Swamiji explains. This knowledge is of two kinds – the inferior and the superior. The superior knowledge, the subject knowledge, is about our real identity. Pursuing the attainment of that knowledge is the purpose of the human life. PR 17 Jan 2017

item.title: Advaita Understanding Gives Non-Affectation and Contentment - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji says that the concept of Advaita rises only when, by in-depth introspection, we are not able to find any justification for the objects, space, and changes to be physically or in reality there. The entire world exists. This existence of the world is actually a feeling, a comprehension in our mind. Mind is actually Consciousness, its expression. This Advaita understanding is not to negate and invalidate everything in the world, but not to be deluded by it. PR 05 Jan 2012 PR 24 Oct 2016

item.title: The Importance of Brahmavidya Deeksha - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The Brahmavidya deeksha is the last thing in human life. Also, without it there cannot be any full fulfillment in human life. Moksha, i.e. liberation and freedom, the last of the four-fold puruhartha, can be had only through this deeksha. How do we accomplish this attainment? We have to get into our own inner personality. This is where the deeksha plays its significant role. PR 24 Oct 2016

item.title: Understanding Ego vs. Ahankarah | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: In this short audio, Nutan Swamiji helps us understand the difference between ego and ahankara. While the basic ego is essential — as Swamiji says, it is the hub of our personality, coordinating various functions of the senses, body, and mind — ahankara is different. It refers to the sense of doership and enjoyership that we assign to our activities. We are not responsible for our body, mind, or intelligence; they are all products of nature. It is the false sense of ownership and egoism — ahankara — that leads us into trouble.

item.title: How does Happiness Work? | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: Nutan Swamiji explains that in meditation, we withdraw from all interactions as well as thoughts about the world, the body, and so on. When we completely forget the external world, we are flooded with happiness and bliss. This experience reveals that true bliss comes from within. Once we understand this truth, we see the fallacy of chasing after happiness. In reality, it is our desires that keep us unhappy. Joy is a natural quality of the Soul, always welling up from within. When all desires (and hatred) are eliminated, we can attain true happiness and permanent joy.

item.title: The Secret to Happiness | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: We seek happiness from many sources. In reality, everything we do is aimed at achieving happiness. However, our experiences show that we never attain lasting happiness. If we look around the world, we can easily observe that no one has ever become truly happy by pursuing worldly things, yet we persist in believing, "I will be happy if I do this." Through the story of young Bhoja, Nutan Swamiji illustrates how futile it is to think we can achieve eternal happiness by gaining anything in this world. Swamiji teaches us that happiness is an expression of the Soul, and it is our desires that obstruct our natural joy. When we eliminate these desires, we automatically find happiness.

item.title: Relevance of Vedic Culture - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji traces the development of the Hindu civilisation in our country. It started with prayers, followed by rituals, followed by withdrawal, followed by enquiry and finding in the Upanishads. Hinduism, Swamiji says, is not a religion, but a way of life. The basis of our culture are the Puranas, the Gita, the Upanishads, the Brahma Sutras, and the itihasas, namely, the Ramayana and the Mahabharata PR 26 Aug 2017

item.title: How to Handle Depression - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Poojya Swamiji gives spiritual tips to combat depression. It is not correct, he says, to keep thinking of negative qualities one might have. Rather one must try to develop the opposite virtues. Reliance on God, particularly based on a mantra, also instills confidence in a person to accept whatever comes in life and move forward. The same God is present in one’s own being. Thinking thus takes away fear and depressive thoughts. PR 05 Aug 2018

item.title: Brahmavidya Deeksha and Meditation - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The mind, intelligence, and the ego, are but the functions of the inner consciousness. In Brahmavidya deeksha, Poojya Swamiji explains, we straightaway enter into the inner consciousness plane. It is primarily an inspiration, a divine inspiration the Guru lets loose in you. Swamiji explains the specifics of the Vedantic meditation to be undertaken after the deeksha. PR 20 Apr 2017

item.title: The Path of Knowledge-austerity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description:
In jñāna niṣṭa, our focus is sublimating, overcoming, outliving, transcending rāga dvesha bhaya. Every word that one utters will be with a view to overcome and sublimate these. Every book one reads will be for this purpose. The tapas becomes jñāna tapas when the ingredients of tapas, austerity are mind and intelligence.

PR 03 Mar 2018

item.title: Self-Realization and the Process to achieve it - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji explains the nature of Self-realization. It is not just meditative absorption. The realisation of the Self, that is all-pervading, all-permeating, cannot be limited to a realization in the heart. Self-realization is actually a qualitative improvement in the seeker. The quality and character of the mind and intelligence change. The mind becomes purer, the intelligence grows in clarity. That is how the Self-realization becomes more wholesome, static, and relevant. PR 04 Nov 2011

item.title: Daily Spiritual Practices - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The questioner asks about daily spiritual practices. Swamiji says that daily spiritual practice should be such that some time should be spent away from the objects, trying to interact with the subject. Then our inner personality becomes more and more imbued with the grandeur of the subject. Contemplation on the very source of thought, the thinker and the thinking substance, this is the essential practice that should be incorporated in the daily routine.

item.title: Who am I - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The questioner asks “Who am I”. Swamiji says that the ‘I’ denotes a definite presence in the body to which everything else in this world is related including the body. Our entire spiritual science is based on this ‘I’. It has a magnitude that includes even the universe. In seeking it, the purpose of human life is fulfilled.

item.title: What is needed to start meditation? - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The questioner wants to know what is needed to start meditation, and if it involves concentration. Swamiji replies that meditation is a mento-intellectual effort. Thought and reason are the natural focus of meditation. Swamiji explains the process of meditation in steps and the use of an optional thought to lead the seeker to samadhi.

item.title: Self Knowledge - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji says how this self-realization works and brings about fruition and fulfillment is something we should know. When the mind recedes from desires, the craving for sensory enjoyment drops, the senses are brought under control, the knowledge comes that the Self within can produce all the enjoyment. Such people attain the supreme knowledge of the Self. PR 08 May 2018

item.title: The Importance of Austerity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha highlights how austerity provides all the sublimity, power, purity, tolerance and forebearance to dedicate one’s life wholesomely for the welfare of others. It is the wisdom and austerity alone that leads to an attitudinal change, dedicating one to perform with mental relaxation, delight and an expansive, cheerful attitude. Swamiji states that this is what the Bhagavad Gita describes as acting in an actionless spirit. Abiding in the spiritual luminosity in the sentience space within, with an enlightened intelligence and dissolved ego, is the austere life lived by Swamiji and the inmates in Narayanashrama Tapovanam. Swamiji further cautions that it is the lack of austerity that leads one to be intolerant, irritated, impatient and other such degrading thoughts and behaviours. Shlokas chanted in the Track: मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्तः सङ्गवर्जितः । निर्वैरः सर्वभूतेषु यः स मामेति पाण्डव ।। Bhagavad Gita 11.55 सर्वकर्माण्यपि सदा कुर्वाणो मद्‍व्यपाश्रयः । मत्प्रसादादवाप्नोति शाश्वतं पदमव्ययम् ।। Bhagavad Gita 18.56 PR 27 May 2013

item.title: Importance of Satsang - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha in this Talk, emphasises that Narayanashrama Tapovanam is an abode of spiritual knowledge, exclusively oriented to enrich and purify the mind, intelligence and ego. The Satsang in the Ashram is for Subjective Knowledge, transforming the character, behaviour and interaction by all who apply this Knowledge. This Subjective Knowledge, makes the inner personality free, light, expansive, luminous and joyful. For this, Swamiji quotes the Bhikshu Gita from Srimad Bhagavatam and expounds the depth of the message which on deep reflection and application, transforms the whole being, to the extent that even the environment outside becomes auspicious and divine. Swamiji himself always speaks about the message and application of the scriptures with wisdom orientation to enrich the seekers and the society at large. Shlokas chanted in the Track: नायं जनो मे सुखदुःखहेतुर्न देवतात्मा ग्रहकर्मकालाः। मनः परं कारणमामनन्ति संसारचक्रं परिवर्तयेद्यत्।। Śrīmad Bhāgavatam 11.23.42 दानं स्वधर्मो नियमो यमश्च श्रुतं च कर्माणि च सद्व्रतानि । सर्वे मनोनिग्रहलक्षणान्ताः परो हि योगो मनसः समाधिः ॥ Srimad Bhagavatam 11.23.45 PR 27 Feb 2017

item.title: Renunciation of Desires is moksha - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In Yoga Vasistha Ramayana, Sage Vasistha enlightens, Sri Rama, that desires are the cause of all bondage. We have latent tendencies and desires coiled up in the mind. Moksha is the extinction of all desires. Swamiji emphasizes that it is possible for the mind to generate contentment by itself. In reality, there is no place or need for desires. Starting with external things, sannyasins renounce lucrative jobs, blood relations, and more importantly, renounce greed, untruthfulness, possessiveness and ego. How to renounce the desires of the mind? Aspiration or desire for liberation can be cultivated which will replace desires for external objects. After leaving object desires, the desire for knowing the Self also has to be left. The secret of spiritual wisdom is that a mind free of desires enjoys supreme peace and contentment. Shlokas chanted in the Track: बन्धो हि वासनाबन्धो मोक्षः स्याद् वासनाक्षयः । वासनां त्वं परित्यज्य मोक्षार्थित्वमपि त्यज ।। Laghuyogavāsiṣṭha Rāmāyaṇam 4.5.20 PR 17 Apr 2010

item.itunes:summary: In Yoga Vasistha Ramayana, Sage Vasistha enlightens, Sri Rama, that desires are the cause of all bondage. We have latent tendencies and desires coiled up in the mind. Moksha is the extinction of all desires. Swamiji emphasizes that it is possible for the mind to generate contentment by itself. In reality, there is no place or need for desires. Starting with external things, sannyasins renounce lucrative jobs, blood relations, and more importantly, renounce greed, untruthfulness, possessiveness and ego. How to renounce the desires of the mind? Aspiration or desire for liberation can be cultivated which will replace desires for external objects. After leaving object desires, the desire for knowing the Self also has to be left. The secret of spiritual wisdom is that a mind free of desires enjoys supreme peace and contentment. Shlokas chanted in the Track: बन्धो हि वासनाबन्धो मोक्षः स्याद् वासनाक्षयः । वासनां त्वं परित्यज्य मोक्षार्थित्वमपि त्यज ।। Laghuyogavāsiṣṭha Rāmāyaṇam 4.5.20 PR 17 Apr 2010

item.title: The Mind has the Power to Cling and also Leave - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this Talk, Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha discusses the message given by Lord Krishna to Uddhava in the 11th Skanda of Srimad Bhagavatam. Krishna reveals the grand state of renunciation and non-clinging. Swamiji declares that so long as one is bound to a householder’s life, a person is only half human. It is only the fulfillment of the Sannyasa ashrama, where the quest is exclusively for the Absolute Truth, wanting nothing at all, that the human life is complete. Such a renunciate lets go of everything, never even living for the next day. Here, Swamiji recounts the grandeur of the great Emperor Rishabhadev, who after giving the sermon on Dharma to his sons, renounced the emperorship and lived in the joyful state of austerity. His mortal body simply merged in Nature by the forest fires. Swamiji describes the glory of such a state of renunciation. The human mind has the inexplicable power to willing leave everything in the world for permanent fulfillment. Shlokas chanted in the Track: ज्ञानं विशुद्धं विपुलं यथैतद् वैराग्यविज्ञानयुतं पुराणम् । आख्याहि विश्वेश्वर विश्वमूर्ते त्वद्भक्तियोगं च महद्विमृग्यम् ।। तापत्रयेणाभिहतस्य घोरे संतप्यमानस्य भवाध्वनीश । पश्यामि नान्यच्छरणं तवाङ्घ्रिद्वन्द्वातपत्रादमृताभिवर्षात् ।। दष्टं जनं संपतितं बिलेस्मिन् कालाहिना क्षुद्रसुखोरुतर्षम् । समुद्धरैनं कृपयापवक्यैर्वचोभिरासिञ्च महानुभाव ।। Srimad Bhagavatam- 11.19.8-11.19.10 PR 27 May 2011

item.title: Fixing the Intelligence on God is Austerity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji discusses austerity, emphasizing its different levels and forms. Physical austerity involves acts like prostrating before deities, circumambulating temples, and chanting prayers. Moving beyond the physical, a seeker has to take to austerity of the mind. This includes cultivating positive emotions while eliminating negative ones. Finally, one has to employ the intelligence to ponder on profound questions like the nature of God and the self. By understanding the mind’s workings and recognizing Consciousness as the source of all, true austerity is achieved. Understanding the unity underlying all mental processes is the ultimate goal of austerity. Shlokas chanted in the Track: मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय । निवसिष्यसि मय्येव अत ऊर्ध्वं न संशयः ।। Bhagavad Gita 12.8

item.title: Austerity at the level of the Mind and Intelligence - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Speaking about austerity, Swamiji says that Tapas (austerity) can be of three levels. The physical Austerity is the elimination of whatever one otherwise does generally, or incorporation of something new which one is not used to doing as a daily routine. Tapas in the mind level is when one introduces a thought or a set of thoughts and try to revolve them in the mind like mantra japa, thinking of God etc. Austerity in the intelligence level is when you start contemplating upon God or Self. This is the Austerity where knowledge becomes the goal, knowledge becomes the means, and knowingness becomes the nature! Knowleedge austerity is the highest, noblest level of Austerity. A true seeker, by a process of contemplation, must renounce his possessiveness and ego and reach higher levels of purity. Shlokas Chanted in the Track: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते । Bhagavadgeeta 4.38 सत्यान्नास्ति परो धर्मः।

item.title: The Significance of Austerity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji speaks about the important quality of austerity. He says that a seeker must reflect upon and understand what it means and live an austere life. True austerity should be of the mind, intelligence and heart. In the level of the mind, austerity means, more and more of purity, less and less of impurity. In intelligence level, it should be more and more of the pursuit of spiritual wisdom. Austerity is either one of denial or one of incorporation. It can relate to the body and senses first; mouth next; mind still next; intelligence still further, and finally it can refer to the ‘I’ or the ego. Shlokas chanted in the Track: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते । (Bhagavad Gita-4.38) धर्माणामस्ति सन्न्यासः

item.title: What to learn from an Ashram - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji speaks about what an Ashram is and what one can gain from an Ashram. It is always knowledge interaction that takes place in the Ashram. All the knowledge discussed and shared in the Ashram will be knowledge about the inner personality, its characteristics, its potential, its possibilities. Ashram is a place where the knowledge about the subjective part of our personality and the world is understood, discussed and disseminated. All activities that take place in the Ashram are an amalgamation of lofty spiritual thoughts, spiritual assessments, spiritual knowledge. The teachers in Ashram impart spiritual knowledge and brilliance.

item.title: Take to chanting as austerity: Swamiji's childhood practices - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji shares with his listeners his own love for chanting Sanskrit hymns and shlokas. Right from childhood, the practice of chanting had a purifying and elevating effect on his mind. Swamiji exhorts everyone to take to the austerity of chanting Vishnusahasranama or Bhagavad Gita. This austerity has its sublime and creative effect on the mind, whereby the mind goes on becoming purified. Various distractional thoughts are gone and their place is taken over by the recitation. We come to understand from this talk that somehow we need to steal some time for recitation and build up the stock of austerity. Shlokas chanted in the Track: आयुर्नश्यति पश्यतां प्रतिदिनं याति क्षयं यौवनं प्रत्यायान्ति गताः पुनर्नदिवसाः कालो जगद्भक्षकः । लक्ष्मीस्तोयतरङ्गभङ्गचपला विद्युच्चलं जीवितं तस्मान्माम् शरणागतं शरणद त्वं रक्ष रक्षाधुनाम् ।। Shivaaparadha Kshamapanartha stotram Verse 13 किं वानेन धनेन वाजिकरिभिः प्राप्तेन राज्येन किं किं वा पुत्रकलत्रमित्रपशुभिर्देहेन गेहेन किम् । ज्ञात्वैतत्क्षणभङ्गुरं सपदि रे त्याज्यं मनो दूरतः स्वात्मार्थं गुरुवाक्यतो भज मन श्रीपार्वतीवल्लभम् ।। Shivaaparadha Kshamapanartha stotram Verse 12

item.title: Austerity is the Watchword - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji emphasizes the importance of Austerity in the life of a seeker. It empowers one to penetrate into the mental and intellectual plane and bring refinement and moderation. Defining austerity, Swamiji says that Austerity is an effort to bridle, reform and refine the mind and removing all the undesirable elements in it. Austerity may begin from the sensory, oral and mental level. But the austerity becomes maximum and most central when the intelligence prefers to reflect upon the self and then wants to realize it in its own fullness. Shlokas chanted in the Track: संगच्छध्वं संवदध्वं (Rigveda X-192-2). PR 12 May 2015

item.title: Spiritual Austerity or Tapas - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: What is Spiritual Austerity? Swamiji, in this track, throws light on this subject saying that whatever a seeker does, it has to be with attention, attunement, sublimation and refinement. When these are had, the mind changes its quality, it becomes pure. And as the mind becomes pure, the thoughts, responses and reactions become different. They become purer, more and more sublime, more and more divine. PR 06 Jun 2012

item.title: Self enrichment through austerity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji emphasizes that the Mind and intelligence can be constantly enriched by austerity. A seeker must ensure that every action he/she performs is done with great attention. One has to constantly analyze whether the action is performed in a pure manner, without any clinging to it. A seeker needs to ensure that he performs all activities–secular, religious, social– in an austere manner. Swamiji assures us that this sublimation and enrichment of the mind will bring great joy. Shlokas chanted in the talk: यज्ञदानतप:कर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत् । यज्ञो दानं तपश्चैव पावनानि मनीषिणाम् ॥ Bhagavad Gita 18.5 एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च । कर्तव्यानीति मे पार्थ निश्चितं मतमुत्तमम् ।। (Bhagavad Gita 18.6) तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर । असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्‍नोति पूरूषः ॥ Bhagavad Gita 3.19 न कर्मणा न प्रजया धनेन त्यागेनैके अमृतत्वमानशुः ।। (Kaivalyopanishad 3) PR 10 Aug 2009

item.title: Austerity and Sannyasa - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this beautiful talk, Poojya Swamiji discusses the importance of austerity in the life of a seeker. Each spiritual aspirant will have to examine himself/herself to find out whether he/she is austere enough. Quoting relevant verses from the Bhagavad Gita, Swamiji exhorts everyone to reflect over the Bhagavad Gita verses and make sure that they embody ample austerity in their own lives. Shlokas chanted in the talk: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः । (Bhagavad Gita 5.17) PR 09 Nov 2012

item.title: Renunciation is of the Mind II - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji speaks about the inner and sublime process of renunciation. This renunciation is not meant to be practiced by austere monks alone. It is to be practiced by everyone, in every walk of life. Swamiji says that real renunciation is the renunciation of Sanga (delusional clinging) to everything. A seeker has to diligently find out where the Sanga, attachment is hiding in his own personality and remove it. When one practices the inner renouncement, life would be filled with joy, peace, poise and harmony. PR 09 Jan 2018

item.title: The Triple Practices of Yajna-Dana-Tapas - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The entire Bhagavad Gita speaks and delineates only Tyaga and Sannyasa, Poojya Swamiji says. Then he goes on to explain the triple practices of yajna, dana, and tyaga, and how all three are tyaga alone. item.title: Accept the Scriptures as Wholesome and Enriching - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji says that the body is animated and activated by the power within. The power of animation can be felt only in our living body. Thus, the focus of a seeker must be within. This animating power is the Self, indicated by the term ‘I’. Our shastras are verdicts of the people who have gone into this subject. A seeker must read the shastras, which are guides and pointers to him and he must never doubt them. He must have a frame of mind that accepts all revelations of the shastras as true, enriching, benevolent, wholesome and endearing. How we receive the shastras is most important. We must read them, learn them and understand and actualize them. Every statement of the shastras must be considered as pointers. One must delve deeply into the meaning and import of the statements and try to fully understand them. When we see the shastras as the most dependable, caring, endearing revelations, then our progress will be meteoric on this path! Shlokas Chanted in the Track: सर्वधर्मान्परित्यज्य मामेकं शरणं व्रज । अहं त्वां सर्वपापेभ्यो मोक्षयिष्यामि मा शुचः ।। Bhagavad Gita 18.66 PR 26 Jan 2015

item.title: Use Scriptures as a Guiding Light - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji says that every part of life (whether spiritual or non-spiritual) is manifested by God. The jiva in us, is the Lord himself. The Sadhana is to remove the differential and divisional feeling from one’s own mind. The scriptures, which were written by no one specific person, is the binding force of India. They were evolved by our common ancestors. All scriptures incorporate values relating to the mind and intelligence. Swamiji emphasizes that these scriptural thoughts, value treasures must be upheld. Everyone must take the support offered by the scriptures. Shlokas chanted in the Track: न प्रत्यग्ब्रह्मणोर्भेदं कदापि ब्रह्मसर्गयोः । प्रज्ञया यो विजानाति स जीवन्मुक्तलक्षणः ॥ Vivekachudamani 440 काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः । महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम् ।। Bhagavad Gita 3.37 विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि । शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः ॥ Bhagavad Gita 5.18 PR 22 Apr 2016

item.title: Examples of Gunas from Srimad Bhagavatam - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Shraddha means assiduous attention and application. Shraddha is extremely important, says Swamiji. There is no product anywhere in creation which is not made up of the three gunas-Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. The Shraddha that is manifest in the individual – that also will be governed by what kind of a guna is pronounced in him. Through the Srimad Bhagavatam, Swamiji illustrates each of the three gunas working in the individual. The Sattva Guna is depicted by the 7-year-old boy, Prahlada, whose devotion was unparalleled. Shringi, the son of Shameeka Rishi, displayed Rajo Guna. The moment he came to know of a dead cobra being put around the neck of his meditating father, he pronounced a curse on Pareekshit. The father explained to him that an austere person must be accepting, understanding that the Atma is unaffected, and above the gunas. Dhruva was blessed with Shastra Tejas and with a spirit and fervor of a fighter i.e. Rajoguna. The Rajoguna had continued to assail him even when he was old. Finally, taking the example of Duryodhana from the Mahabharata, Swamiji gives the example of Tamoguna. Shlokas chanted in the Track: तमेव वत्साश्रय भृत्यवत्सलं मुमुक्षुभिर्मृग्यपदाब्जपद्धतिम् । अनन्यभावे निजधर्मभाविते मनस्यवस्थाप्य भजस्व पूरुषम् ॥ Srimad Bhagavatam 4.8.22 PR 26 Oct 2016

item.title: The Essence of All Scriptures is Non-Dual Knowledge - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In the entire Srimad Bhagavatam, what is being spoken about is Jnana (Knowledge), says Swamiji. Although it is considered to be devotional text, it only speaks about Bhakti which leads to Virakti (dispassion) and Bhagavat Prabodhah (Realization of God). In Bhagavatam, Suta muni is asked to explain the essence of all scriptures. He says, “The knowers of Truth say that the essence of all scriptures and allied texts is the Tattva. It is knowledge, that gives no room for a concept of two or Many.The non-dual knowledge is spoken of differently as: 1) Supreme Reality called Brahman or, 2) Paramatma- which we refer to as ‘I’, 3) Bhagavan or the Supreme Lord Almighty.” This is the message of Srimad Bhagavatam – a book on devotion, which actually discusses only the Knowledge and Realization of the Human Mind and Heart. Shlokas chanted in the Track: वदन्ति तत्तत्त्वविदस्तत्त्वं यज्ज्ञानमद्वयम् । ब्रह्मेति परमात्मेति भगवानिति शब्द्यते ।। Srimad Bhagavatam 1.2.11 PR 20 Jan 2012

item.title: Each Episode In Mahabharata has a Deeper Relevance - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji speaks about the great epic Mahabharata, written by Vyasadeva. In his great epic, Vyasadeva conveys deeper meanings through the characters of Karna, Duryodhana etc. He presents how they were inextricably bound by their emotions. Swamiji shares the example of Karna, a complex character from Mahabharata. Karna was great, dangerously charitable and courageous. But he also had the hollow aspects in his personality, which Vyasadeva has revealed in his writings. Karna wanted to stand by the side of Duryodhana all along but his intolerance for Bheeshma made him keep away from the battlefield, till Bheeshma fell. It is this emotional turmoil that Vyasadeva has captured in his writings. PR 23 June 2015

item.title: The Great Cultural History of Our Country - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji speaks about the inestimably glory of our great country, India. Our two great epics Ramayana and Mahabharata have instilled values in countless generations and continue to do so. Ramayana portrayed the great, noble king Sri Rama and through his showed that any human mind has the potential to rise to any lofty level. Mahabharata speaks about the decline of Kuru dynasty and how value decline led to destruction. Yajna (Sacrifices), Dana (charity) and Tapas (austerity) are the spirit of our culture. These are the inspiration with which Indians have been living and facing all the hazards and calamities and finally reaching the goal and fulfillment of life. PR 17 Apr 2013

item.title: Varnashrama dharma in The Bhagavatam - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Sri Krishna speaks about Varnashrama dharmas in Srimad Bhagavatam. Every human is born with some characteristic traits and tendencies inherited biologically, from both parents. Shastras help us to understand the characteristics of each human. They prescribe work according to each person’s Svabhava (Brahmana, Kshatriya, Vaishya and Sudra). Hindu Dharma also classifies the four stages of life of every human. Brahmacharya (where education is acquired), Gaarhastya (householder life is taken up), Vanaprastha and Sannyasa. Swamiji urges all to understand that we belong to a country and a lineage, a society which had cherished these, evolved these, abided by these, and which always remained enriched, inwardly sovereign at every point of time in life. PR 16 Sep 2011

item.title: Hindu Dharma is Absolutely Rational - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this Talk, Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha, shares his reflections on the Bhikshu Gita, from Srimad Bhagavatam. He emphasizes how Hindu Dharma is absolutely rational, totally filled with reason. The intelligence is ever enriched and enlightened by the knowledge of the Supreme Truth. In Spirituality, the intelligence must empower the mind to apply this knowledge to tackle all mental plights, responses and reactions. In Bhagavatam, Sri Krishna explains the wisdom of the Imperishable Soul rationally, thus removing all notions of birth, death, even God. Sri Krishna empowers and illumines the mind of Uddhava, through the Song of the Bhikshu. PR 20 Nov 2013

item.title: Ramayana and Hindu Dharma - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji details how the Epics are not mere historical descriptions, but actually give through them, the values and inspiring lives of all the characters. Ramayana was composed by Sage Valmiki, who got transformed from the dacoit Ratnakara into a saint. Through the close association of the saints, he got free from all his sins. Through the poetic composition of the Ramayana, Sage Valmiki depicts the life of Maryada Purusha Shree Rama as well as all the characters in the kingdom of Ayodhya during the Treta Yuga. Swamiji speaks about the degradation of this lofty Dharma of our country today. There are malpractices in the temples and other religious worships. Various practices are polluting the minds and the society at large, instead of making people inculcate purity through the devotional practices. In this talk, Swamiji gives a clarion call not to fall a trap to these wrong doings in the name of devotion. Shlokas chanted in the Track: मा निषाद प्रतिष्ठां त्वमगमः शाश्वतीः समाः । यत् क्रौञ्चमिथुनादेकमवधीः काममोहितम् ।। वाल्मीकीरामायणम् बालकाण्डम् १.२.१५ को न्वस्मिन् साम्प्रतं लोके गुणवान् कश्च वीर्यवान् । (वाल्मीकीरामायणम् बालकाण्डम् १-१-२) PR 16 Apr 2016

item.title: Hinduism is very rational - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this Talk, Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha reveals how Hinduism is extremely rational, whether it is through devotional or logical paths. Quoting from the supreme devotional text the conversation between Uddhava and Sri Krishna, or the mento-intellectual supreme knowledge regarding Brahman / Self and the world being a display of Consciousness or even the instructions given to Arjuna by Sri Krishna in the Bhagavad Gita, Swamiji highlights that every scripture reveals through deep analysis, the Supreme Truth. This makes devotion and Godly love even more sustained and intense and the devotee with this mento intellectual understanding, drowns in Spiritual ecstasy. Thus, with several examples, Swamiji clarifies that whether it is devotion or knowledge, the Truth is exposed in the most rational manner, thus removing all confusions, doubts and delusions. Shlokas chanted in the track: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः । Bhagavad Gita 2.16 कात्यायनि महामाये महायोगिन्यधीश्वरि । नन्दगोपसुतं देवि पतिं मे कुरु ते नम: । Srimad Bhagavatam 10.22.4 PR 22 Aug 2018

item.title: The Essence of Scriptures - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji urges that we should try to find out the essence of the shastras. We should sift the essence of shastras and hold on to it. Sukha and dukha are the only 2 experiences the entire world provides. A seeker must never foster a preference to one and prejudice to the other, as they follow each other. This is irresistibly had by us due to our interactions with the world. Then what are we supposed to do? Become a ‘Nirdvandva’, says Swamiji. Try to rise above both. Take away the preference and prejudice and allow sukha and dukha to be what they are. Then we have taken away the sting from both and we arrive at a level of transcendence. This is the gist of the entire shastras. All explanations are only confirmations of this basic point. Texts like Bhagavad Gita, Yogavasishtha and other scriptures speak about this. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अनन्तशास्त्रं बहुवेदितव्यं स्वल्पश्च कालो बहवश्च विघ्नाः । यत्सारभूतं तदुपासितव्यं हंसो यथा क्षीरमिवाम्बुमिश्रम् ।। Subhashitam समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः । शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु समः सङ्गविवर्जितः ।। Bhagavad Gita 12.18 निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते ।। Bhagavad Gita 5.3

item.title: Understand the Contrasts in Human Mind Through Mahabharata - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji speaks on Mahabharata, mainly on the characterization of a few individuals to bring forth an understanding of the human mind and personality. Our body is a biological aggregate which we look after by food, nourishment and exercise. Our inner personality comprising of the mind and intelligence undergoes all the changes, improvements, enrichments. This inner personality defines our character, behavior and interactions. Mahabharata discusses the nature of this inner personality, its potential, possibilities, and gives us the history of our predecessors. Swamiji speaks at length about the human mind, its emotions, it’s excellences and being victimized by itself, sharing the story of how the 8th child of Shantanu and Ganga, Bhishma, came to be. Swamiji marvels at the pen of VedaVyasa which presents many contrasts in the Mahabharata.

item.title: The Relevance of Mahabharata VIII - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this beautiful talk, Swamiji gives the examples of some of the epic characters from Mahabharatam–Draupadi, Arjuna, Bheeshma and Drona. In different times and situations, they had to face intolerable mental challenges and agony. Spirituality says that whether it is a physical torture or a mental torment there is a way of transcending both. There is something called the way of transcendence, the way of surrender, the way of clarity, the way of impersonal and impartial neutrality. That is called the Soul or God. That is called the wisdom of God and the wisdom of the soul. There everything dissolves. Citing various examples in and before the Kurukshetra war, Swamiji says that Bhagavad Gita is an answer and a redress and a solution for all kinds of developments in this world– physical, mental, intellectual or otherwise. Shlokas chanted in the Track: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभाव: पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेता: | यच्छ्रेय: स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम् || Bhagavad Gita 2.7 प्रीतोऽस्मि पुत्र युध्यस्व जयमाप्नुहि पाण्डव । Bheeshma Parva, Mahabharatam, 6-41-34 अर्थस्य पुरुषो दासो दासस्त्वर्थो न कस्यचित् । इति सत्यं महाराज बद्धोऽस्मर्थ्येन कौरवैः ।। Bheeshma Parva, Mahabharatam, 6-41-36

item.title: Ashtavakra Samhita - A Straightforward Presentation of Spiritual Science - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Ashtavakra Samhita, is a conversation between King Janaka and Ashtavakra Maharishi. King Janaka asked sage Ashtavakra to enlighten him on Jnana, Mukti and dispassion. Spirituality is a psycho intellectual science. All panchabhutas are inert but we are sentient. Is the mind the final truth or is it a function of something else? Spirituality takes up this probe. When we take up this probe, we realise that everything around us is changing physically and chemically. Our body-mind personality too is transforming but we have an unchanging ‘I’ within. Purity of mind and refinement of intelligence lead us to the state of Self-Realization. As we drop desires and possessiveness and have no ego about anything, we become more pure and the self reveals itself to us. The ‘I’ is within, closer than the mind, intelligence and ego. Sage Ashtavakra presents this in a simple and straightforward manner.

item.title: Scriptures Are Means to an End - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji emphasizes that spiritual seekers require love, devotion, and association to a living guru to progress in their spiritual practice. The initiation and blessings from a guru holds great importance, as sādhana revolves around the guru’s guidance. Scriptures, such as the Upanishads and Bhagavad Gita, serve as guides to realizing the truth. However, mere reading of scriptures without realizing the truth is futile. Swamiji highlights on focus on sādhana rather than extensive reading. Overall, love, devotion, association with a guru, and realization through sādhana are deemed crucial in the spiritual journey, alongside the role of scriptures. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अविज्ञाते परे तत्त्वे शास्त्राधीतिस्तु निष्फला । विज्ञातेऽपि परे तत्त्वे शास्त्राधीतिस्तु निष्फला ।। Vivekachudamani 59 परीक्ष्य लोकान् कर्मचितान् ब्राह्मणो निर्वेदमायान्नास्त्यकृतः कृतेन । तद्विज्ञानार्थं स गुरुमेवाभिगच्छेत् समित्पाणिः श्रोत्रियं ब्रह्मनिष्ठम् ।। Mundakopanishad-1.2.12

item.title: Importance of Scriptures in Sadhana - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The Sadhana of studying scriptures must be diligently practiced by a seeker, says Swamiji. Scriptures speak about devotion, restfulness in God, ephemerality of the world, dispassion, God, Self etc. They discuss how a seeker should do Sadhana to attain his goal. Scriptures throw light on the wholesome pursuit of the seeker. After reading or listening to the scriptures, one must absorb some of the cardinal points relevant to one’s own sadhana. Swamiji urges seekers to select and learn fifty verses which would represent their own Sadhana. These verses, once absorbed, would become a permanent wealth and help for the seeker. The verses would help him assess how much he has grown in his spiritual pursuit, what are the qualities to be incorporated, what are the traits to be discarded etc.

item.title: The Impact of Srimad Bhagavatam on The Human Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In Srimad Bhagavatam there are twelve Skandhas, says Swamiji. These twelve skandhas are the raw materials which have to fed into one’s own mind. By the time one comes to the twelfth skandha, all the impurities of the mind are dissolved. The mind becomes beautiful and full of devotion. In the tenth Skandha, Bhagavatam discusses Sri Krishna’s birth, growth and exploits. The Bhāgavata author found that for the human mind to hold on to, there must be a beautiful and alluring character to hold on to. So, he presented Sri Krishna. Krishna faced a lot of adverse situations in his life but faced everything with a smile and acceptance. In the most conflicting and opposing environments, he did not lose his inner splendor, glory, potential and greatness. Swamiji urges all seekers to follow his example and strengthen and refine their own Mind and intelligence.

item.title: Cherish the Scriptures and be Nourished by it - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Speaking about scriptures, Swamiji says that a seeker must read and understand the scriptures and find his delight and inspiration in them. He has to cherish them and be nourished by them. Each scriptural narration speaks to the seeker as if it is his/her best friend, teacher or a parent. Hey are the great gift and treasure of mankind. There will be an answer in the scriptural narrations for every question in one’s life. For every need there will be fulfillment in the scriptures. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते । तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम् ।। (Bhagavad Gita 9.22)

item.title: The Relevance of Mahabharata VI - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji in this message speaks about the different Yugas and explains how the decline started in the society. In Krita Yuga, everyone was happy, contented and fulfilled. But it gradually declined and there was a need for a monarch in Treta Yuga to maintain order and discipline. In Dvapara Yuga, independent thoughts and aspiration became strong and people took to argumentation and logic. Swamiji gives the example of the Kuru assembly where the Pandavas lost in the game of dice and everyone was given a chance to argue and present their case. Shlokas chanted in the track: कृते तु कृतकृत्यत्वात् त्रेतायाम् नृपशासने द्वापरे तर्कचातुर्य

item.title: How Epic Narrations are the Prevailing Influence in Humanity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji speaks about our epic narrations–Ramayana and Mahabharata. He says that throughout these epic narrations there is a constant effort to inculcate in the minds of the readers and the listeners a fourfold human objective–Dharma, Artha, Kama and Moksha. Personal stories are the prevailing influence in humanity every time. They offer inspiration, ideal, compulsion, persuasion, commitment, dedication, sacrifice and what not. The epics depict stories and show how to deal with any situation. Shlokas chanted in the Track: स्त्रीशूद्रद्विजबन्धूनां त्रयी न श्रुतिगोचरा । इति भारतमाख्यानं कृपया मुनिना कृतम् ।। Srimad Bhagavatam 1.4.25

item.title: Inculcate Values from Ramayana - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this short audio, Swamiji points out the two values that one can definitely imbibe from the eternal epic, Ramayana. “This is my friend, this is not so”, this kind of a divisional approach and attitude is there only in the constricted and narrow minds. For a one of noble conduct, the entire earth is one’s family. One has to consider the whole universe as one’s own family. The second value is: Motherland and everything about the Motherland is far superior to even the heaven. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अयं बन्धुरयं नेति गणना लघुचेतसाम् । उदारचरितानां तु वसुधैव कुटुम्बकम् ॥ अपि स्वर्णमयी लङका न मे लक्ष्मण रोचते । जननी जन्मभूमिश्च स्वर्गादपि गरीयसी ॥

item.title: The Relevance of Mahabharata - I - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji speaks about the epics-Ramayana and Mahabharata-which the world will always need. Ramayana tells the world of beautiful things with sacrifices and Mahabharata tells us of the greatest of conflicts and contradictions and how to remain firm and unshakable in all of them. They record the history of the human mind, the behavior of individuals and families and even monarchs and consequently what the society had to undergo. We are able to see how humanity handled numerous challenges and diversities and emerged triumphant.

item.title: Message from the Three Children of Srimad Bhagavatam - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Vedvyasa presents the story of three children in Srimad Bhagavatam. In this track, Swamiji discusses each of these stories and explains what the message is for a seeker. The first story is of Shameeka Maharishi’s son Shringi who cursed king Pareekshit. Shameeka Maharishi’s response to this curse shows us how to teach the younger generation. The second story is of the little boy Dhruva who is guided by his mother to go to the forest to propitiate Lord Hari. Srimad Bhagavatam, through this story, tells us how to test our own devotion. The third story is of young Prahlada who remained steadfast in his devotion to Sri Hari. Through these stories, Bhagavatam tells us about the majesty of the human mind. Swamiji exhorts all seekers to absorb all the messages and find out where the correction is needed. Shlokas chanted in the track: यत आत्मागुणाश्रयः (Srimad Bhagavatam-1.18.50) योऽन्तःप्रविश्य मम वाचमिमां प्रसुप्तां संजीवयत्यखिलशक्तिधरः स्वधाम्ना । अन्यांश्च हस्तचरणश्रवणत्वगादीन् प्राणान् नमो भगवते पुरुषाय तुभ्यम् ।। (Śrīmad Bhāgavatam 4.9.6)

item.itunes:summary: Vedvyasa presents the story of three children in Srimad Bhagavatam. In this track, Swamiji discusses each of these stories and explains what the message is for a seeker. The first story is of Shameeka Maharishi’s son Shringi who cursed king Pareekshit. Shameeka Maharishi’s response to this curse shows us how to teach the younger generation. The second story is of the little boy Dhruva who is guided by his mother to go to the forest to propitiate Lord Hari. Srimad Bhagavatam, through this story, tells us how to test our own devotion. The third story is of young Prahlada who remained steadfast in his devotion to Sri Hari. Through these stories, Bhagavatam tells us about the majesty of the human mind. Swamiji exhorts all seekers to absorb all the messages and find out where the correction is needed. Shlokas chanted in the track: यत आत्मागुणाश्रयः (Srimad Bhagavatam-1.18.50) योऽन्तःप्रविश्य मम वाचमिमां प्रसुप्तां संजीवयत्यखिलशक्तिधरः स्वधाम्ना । अन्यांश्च हस्तचरणश्रवणत्वगादीन् प्राणान् नमो भगवते पुरुषाय तुभ्यम् ।। (Śrīmad Bhāgavatam 4.9.6)

item.title: Preserve Our Culture - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji speaks about India’s great Spiritual heritage which has been preserved for many generations. Every generation has had dedicated people who mastered it and passed it to the next generation. Even now, there are many ascetics who are involved in the propagation of this eternal knowledge. When one goes to a Guru who is already in the mission of disseminating spiritual wisdom, then one has to try to do the sādhana in the way of śravaṇa, manana and nididhyāsana and then also be a part of the Guru’s mission. Swamiji exhorts his disciples to have the feeling that they are also part of this dissemination mission that contributes to the rich culture of the country.

item.title: The Importance of Prasthana Trayam - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this audio, Swamiji discusses the subject of ‘Prasthana Trayam’. The word ‘Prasthāna’ means a voyage in the area or region of knowledge– it is a knowledge voyage. The Upanishads, Brahma Sutras and Bhagavad Gita constitute the ‘Prasthana Traya’. They deal with the knowledge about the mind, intelligence and ego and the character, behavior and interactions of an individual. ‘Prasthāna-trayam’ is the one written record before us which clearly tell us what we are, who we are, how our ancients were, for what did we give the supreme value in life and how that supreme goal was fulfilling in every way and how this becomes the real human quest. Shlokas chanted in this track: इहचेदवेदीदथ सत्यमस्ति न चेदिहावेदीन्महती विनष्टिः । Kenopanishad 2.5 तस्मादसक्त: सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर | असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुष: || Bhagavad Gita–3.19 PR 06 Oct 2017

item.title: Learn Poetry to Imbibe Qualities - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji speaks about the influence of Sanskrit poetry in his own life of Sadhana. His mind was greatly impressed by the verses, and it automatically imbibed them and stored them. Because of this Sadhana through poetry, the whole pursuit became joyful and natural. Swamiji exhorts all seekers to learn the poems and keep them as an inner treasure and be nourished by them. Shlokas chanted in the track: अथातो ब्रह्मजिज्ञासा देहाभिमाने गळिते विज्ञाते परमात्मनि । यत्र यत्र मनो याति तत्र तत्र समाधयः ।। (DrgDrsyaViveka 30) वासनाक्षयविज्ञानमनोनाशा महामते । समकालं चिराभ्यस्ता भवन्ति फलदा मुने ।। (Yogavasishta Ramayanam, Upasama Prakaranam – 5.92.17) नायमात्मा प्रवचनेन लभ्यो (Mundakopanishad 3.2.3) ज्ञानप्रसादेन विशुद्धसत्त्वः (Mundakopanishad 3.1.8) नैष्कर्म्येण न तस्यार्थो न तस्यार्थोऽस्ति कर्मभिः । न समाधिजपाभ्यां वा यस्य निर्वासनं मनः ।। (Laghu Yogavasishtha 4.5.28) भूयिष्ठं भव दक्षिणा परिजने (Abhijñata Shākuntalam, 4th bhagam, Verse 98) PR 06 Nov 2015

item.title: Points For Sadhana Day - 7 | Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: In this talk, Ma enlightens the seekers about the captivating composition of Vyasa Deva -Bhagavatam. She explains that the purpose of this beautiful scripture is to give confidence and assurance to the seekers, especially the householders, that the Sadhana can also be following the path of pure and loving Devotion to Lord Sri Hari - Krishna. It can and will lead us to Self-Realization. Speaking about the uniqueness of Bhagavatam, Ma tells us that the scripture answers the questions- Who is God? What is devotion? Who is a true devotee? What are the qualities of a devotee? Bhagavatam describes the Lord, His appearance, His features, smile, pranks in such a vivid manner that it invokes a sense of loving devotion in the listener. Ma says that the descriptive Shlokas impress upon the Sadhaka’s mind the purity of the Atma. Chanting the shlokas, Ma informs us that constant remembrance of the Lotus feet of Krishna, will evoke deep love for Lord Hari. By this love, one will gain knowledge and will grow in vairagya for the worldly objects. Krishna represents Pure Knowledge, Truth, Bliss, and Purity. Ma tells us that simple, selfless, motiveless devotion has the power to dissolve all grief, delusion and fear. Ma reminds us that human birth is not easy to attain. Having attained this, worship and surrender to the Lord is the way to reach the goal.

item.title: Points For Sadhana Day - 6 | Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: Continuing her discourse on Sadhana, Ma Gurupriya ji calls upon the seekers to constantly keep the goal of Sadhana in mind through all activities and interactions. Chanting a verse from Vivekachoodamani, Ma urges the listeners to follow the Guru's instructions and reflect deeply. Ma stresses on the fact that reflection leads to purification of the mind which will lead to Self-Realization. Ma exhorts us to understand that the intelligence has to be sharpened through constant Vichara (Introspection). A pure and subtle intelligence will, slowly but surely, take the seeker to his goal. Therefore, says Ma, one must stay connected to the Self throughout the day, through all activities and interactions. 'Abhyasa’ or the practice of constant contemplation on the Atma is a must. Ma highlights the need and importance of self-effort in this journey. This subtle and lofty knowledge requires focussed attention and effort. Inattention has to be avoided. Ma explains that to attain the goal one has to, in all earnestness, look within, identify and reject all undesirable traits, the subtle and hidden tendencies and strengthen the virtues. Ma warns us that the worldly desires are simply waiting to tempt and mislead us. So, one must at all times allow discrimination (Viveka) to keep us focussed on our goal. Ma reassures the seekers that a true Shishya need not fear because Guru Kripa will flow and help his Viveka to be alert and sharp. Exhorting the listeners to chant the slokas from the scriptures, Ma tells us how a Self-Realized person acts and interacts in the world. He may be externally doing anything, but he is internally stable, seated in the self and experiencing bliss. If a person has had this experience, will he like to chase after worldly objects anymore, asks Ma.

item.title: Points For Sadhana Day - 5 | Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: In this talk, Ma Gurupriya ji reiterates that the goal of Sadhana is Self Realization/ identifying our true nature. All the scriptures and the Gurus have at length described the nature of the Self. Ma says that when one attains this state, one experiences eternal bliss and one becomes expansive, universal and free of all constrictions and limitations. Ma reminds us of the three steps to be followed very diligently in our Sadhana - Sravana, Manana and Nididhyasana. Ma says that Sravana or listening to the Guru's teachings with one -pointed attention is very important. But, more crucial than listening is to reflect on his teachings (Manana) and meditation on the Truth (Nidhidhyasana). Ma asks the listeners to assess the obstacles in their own sadhana. Ma highlights the fact that it is our very own tendencies, traits, desires and Gunas which constrict our minds. They create preferences and prejudices and cause immense suffering. Ma quotes from the scriptures and tells us that a true sadhaka must 1) Do manana and identify the subtle and hidden desires, attachment and possessiveness and eliminate them. 2) Cultivate virtues of truthfulness, compassion, forbearance, straightforwardness etc. This alone will make our minds pure and restful, says Ma.

item.title: Points For Sadhana Day - 4 | Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: In this talk, Ma reiterates that all scriptures reassure the seeker that a Guru unconditionally imparts this lofty knowledge to a qualified Shishya who has intense yearning to know the truth. The compassionate Guru lights the lamp of knowledge and dispels the darkness of ignorance. The Guru shows the definite path to go across the worldly ocean and instills a sense of fearlessness. Ma says that to be worthy of this knowledge, the Shishya must also do Sadhana and put in intense self effort. Devotion, steadfastness, meditation on the Self is necessary to actualise this knowledge. Discussing the subject further, Ma explains that a seeker’s Sadhana involves listening (Shravana), Reflection or introspection (Manana), and Meditation on the Truth (Nididhyasana). Ma highlights the role of listening in spiritual progress. The Shishya, Ma asserts, must be attentive, focussed, wholesome and one-pointed when listening to the Guru's instructions. He must have a deep longing to know the truth and must ask whatever questions that spring up in his mind. Ma assures us that the Guru is only too happy to remove the doubts of the Shishya, enlighten him, help him cultivate deep Vairagya and develop Viveka which are the necessary pillars of this Lofty Knowledge.

item.title: Points For Sadhana Day - 3 | Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: In this talk, Ma Gurupriya ji helps the listeners to visualise an intense seeker, sitting at the feet of a Guru with an attitude of total surrender. Ma discusses the reason why a seeker comes to the Guru's abode and seeks refuge at the Guru's feet. He is troubled and tormented by the interactions with the world and he would like to know if there is a way to be free of his fears, doubts, confusion and sorrow. Ma discusses a verse from Vivekachoodamani where a seeker seeks guidance from the Guru. Chanting this heart-stirring verse, Ma explains that the seeker's prayer is indeed our prayer. We all want to cross this worldly ocean and be free of all torment and misery. Ma implores the listeners to identify with the sloka and feel the intensity of yearning of the seeker’s heart. Ma assures us that when a seeker comes and asks for guidance, the Guru immediately instructs the seeker on the way forward. He will instruct that knowledge of the Self which is the remedy for all the suffering in this world. Driven by his own compassion and selflessness, he takes the seeker’s hand and leads him to the abode of fearlessness. By his words of wisdom and guidance, he uplifts the mind of the seeker.

item.title: Points For Sadhana Day - 2 | Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: Ma Gurupriya ji, in this talk, enlightens the listeners on what makes a seeker 'eligible' for spiritual wisdom. She states very categorically that having realized that life has a higher purpose, one must make a wholehearted effort towards attaining it. One-pointed focus and a deep sense of renunciation are the key ingredients of sadhana. Ma emphasizes that one must persevere as a Shishya and become fit or eligible to receive this knowledge of the Self. Quoting Shankaracharya, Ma exhorts a seeker to go to a Guru. A Guru alone can lead a seeker forward, enlighten him and establish him in this Truth. Ma discusses the 'Sadhana Chatushtaya’ (four-fold qualities of a seeker) which are described in the scriptures. Explaining them in detail, Ma says that these four-fold qualities are necessary for any seeker who yearns for fulfilment and liberation. Ma warns us against becoming complacent in one’s Sadhana. Ma also highlights the importance of surrendering at the feet of a Guru. The Guru will remove the hindrances in our spiritual path and help us to grow and realize our Atma, says Ma.

item.title: Points For Sadhana Day - 1 | Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: This discourse series by Swamini Ma Gurupriya was part of the Gurupoornima Retreat 2022 program at Narayanashrama Tapovanam, Kerala. In this talk, Ma draws a seeker’s attention to the all-important spiritual pursuit or Sadhana. Sharing the wisdom from various scriptures like Vivekachoodamani, Bhagavatam and the Bhagavad Gita, Ma highlights the fact that human life has a higher purpose - to realize our True identity. And the goal of our Sadhana is to be embraced by this Soul identity. Soulfully chanting the verses, Ma tells us that, as Sadhakas, we should feel grateful that we are blessed with three things. a) Having had a human birth which helps us to do Vichara. It enables us to reflect, introspect and ask questions. It also helps us to see the impermanence of the worldly objects and recognise the eternal nature of our Soul within. b) Having a burning desire for liberation. Our Sadhana lies in making this yearning more intense and deeper. c) Lasty, but most importantly, Ma underlines the fact that we are indeed very fortunate to have a Sadguru in our lives. For, a Guru alone will guide us and give direction to our Sadhana to progress towards our goal- to realize our universal dimension. Quoting from the scriptures, Ma reminds us that a wise person should not waste time. He/she should make sincere efforts to understand and realize the Atma -his/her true nature.

item.title: Introspect Over Scriptural Statements - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji reveals how scriptural reading and introspection work on the human personality. Arjuna despite being religious, pious, austere and knowledgeable, crumbled on the battlefield in front of all his elders. This resulted in a dialogue between Sri Krishna and Arjuna, where Krishna enlightened the intelligence of Arjuna. A seeker must read the Gita, absorb and understand it, think about it and assimilate the whole message by reading and thinking over and over again. That is the true sadhana, a pilgrimage for the mind within the body. The real sadhana is studying the Gita and reflecting on its messages, doing a mind and intellect sadhana. The real sadhana is only the attitude and objective of the mind and the evaluation of the intelligence. We imbibe purity with more reading and understanding of the Gita verses and this makes us more spatial. Swamiji ends this talk by telling us that we must introspect, evaluate and do a self-verification by reading the scriptures. item.title: Introspection should be a Corollary of your Activity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Through this talk, Swamiji throws light on Sadhana and how one can cultivate sufficient inspiration and commitment towards it. The focal point is our Buddhi, which has to become resolute and determined. Desires and hatred make the mind swing. In desire, one has slipped from the self-concept. When we are in grief, do we ask ourselves why we are having grief, as we are the Self? Such introspection is important. As seekers, we cannot allow our mind to be overtaken by things that we have no control on. A seeker’s mind must be constantly given to Vichara. One must introspect, even while doing physical activity. Self-reflection should be a corollary of whatever we do. One must observe the agitation within, dissolving it in the mind. Introspection must be truthful and infusional and the agitation should be lessened and finally dissolved by this introspection. When faced with an unpleasant situation, when in grief, we must not allow the mind to become cheerless and heavy. We must keep the mind cheerful through introspection. Shlokas chanted in the Track: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन । बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् ॥ vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana । bahuśākhā hyanantāśca buddhayo’vyavasāyinām ॥ Bhagavad Gita 2.41 गच्छतस्तिष्ठतो वापि जाग्रतः स्वपतोऽपि वा । न विचारमयं चेतो यस्यासौ मृत उच्यते ।। Yogavasishtaramayanam, Upaśamaprakaranam 93-15 PR 26 Feb 2015

item.title: Manana to Imbibe a Quality - II - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji urges us to recognize that as humans we are mental beings and not just physical beings. The Sentient Consciousness animates and activates the body, mind, intelligence and ego. So, the whole focus should be on the mind, which is the functional display of the Consciousness. Recognizing the supremacy of the mind, a seeker must love, imbibe and dedicatedly pursue the qualities with fervor, zeal and yearning, to make the mind good, noble, benevolent, enriched, elevated and expansive. Swamiji exhorts seekers to spend at least fifty mind hours to nurture the qualities. This empowerment of the mind can be developed by Truthful Introspection – Manana. With such a qualitative mind, all interactions by word, thought and deed would be very benevolent and enriching. This Spirituality can be practiced by anybody, focusing on one’s own mind and nurturing qualitative embellishments. PR 25 May 2012

item.title: How to Retain Knowledge - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Through Vivekachudamani, Swamiji explains how despite gaining the Knowledge of the Self, latent desires are sometimes there in a human. When the desires are very strong, it can lead man astray. We find that life in this world is binding and afflicting, but what binds and afflicts is our strong sense of doership, enjoyership and sufferership. This Ego-centric feeling which grips us, is responsible for the continuation of worldliness. This lingering effect of doership and enjoyership on the mind, can be overcome only by an effort of the mind. By constant and consistent practice of contemplating on the unaffected, unconditional, blissful nature of the Self, rubbing this thought against the existing affliction, one can weaken the strong hold of the feeling of doership and enjoyership. By Vichara, slowly the feeling of doership and enjoyership will become weak and make the seeker a happy and contented person. Swamiji exhorts all seekers to spend mind hours to bring about a transformation in the thinking. Shlokas chanted in the Track: ज्ञाते वस्तुन्यपि बलवती वासनानादिरेषा कर्ता भोक्ताप्यहमिति दृढा यास्य संसारहेतुः । प्रत्यग्दृष्ट्यात्मनि निवसता सापनेया प्रयत्नान् मुक्तिं प्राहुस्तदिह मुनयो वासनातानवं यत् ॥ Vivekachudamani–267 PR 20 Apr 2018

item.title: The Object World is Illusory - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this audio, Swamiji says that though objects are incidental to our experiences, the experience itself is inner, Subjective and personal. Swamiji speaks about his own resistance to considering the objective world as illusory. However, he emphasizes that when he met his Guru and started pursuing the Deeksha Sadhana, along with all the deep study and application of the various Vedantic Shastras, he discovered the Reality of the Subject within, and understood that everything else is objective and illusory. The seeker must be anchored on the magnificence and potential of this Inner Subject. The understanding that the objective world is finite and an illusion, and realization of the Infinite Subject within, can be had by anyone–whether a Housewife, an Enlightened Scholar or an Experienced Seer. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अविद्यमानोऽप्यवभाति हि द्वयो ध्यातुर्धिया Srimad Bhagavatam 11.2.38 यत्र त्रिसर्गोऽमृषा Srimad Bhagavatam 1.1.1 PR 25 Jun 2015

item.title: The Source of Creation - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: When Arjuna crumbled in the battlefield, refusing to fight, Sri Krishna made Arjuna introspect over grief. He empowered Arjuna’s mind by speaking about the Self which is unborn and undying, which is ever-present, never absent. Our senses interact with objects and there are two outcomes of interactions in the mind level–Sukha and Duhkha. They cannot be avoided; they are inevitable. A seeker must forbear them. A seeker treading the spiritual path, must introspect on the source of creation. From the grossest to the subtlest, all things in the world are formful. In Bhagavad Gita, Sri Krishna speaks about the non-dual singular presence and the manifest creation of the world. A seeker must make both these the subject of his enquiry. PR 20 July 2018

item.title: A Pursuit of Knowledge - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji, through this talk, compels us to reflect deeply on the pursuit of Knowledge. Just as the body and senses are employed in our life, our mind and intelligence are also employed. The delusion, which is there in the mind and intelligence, has to be removed by the pursuit of knowledge. The knowledge pursuit is far greater than sensory and oral pursuits. A seeker must cultivate the habit of sensory regulation in Jnana Sadhana. The seeker must cultivate noble virtues to bring about purity of mind. The intelligence must be purified by constant reflection on the Subject. Knowledge alone is the greatest mentor and influencer. Through introspection alone can one purify of mind and intelligence and regulate the senses. When it is done, the spiritual path becomes the best and most rewarding. Shlokas chanted in the Track: प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ।। Bhagavad Gita 5.16 ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः । तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ।। Bhagavad Gita 5.16 तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः । Bhagavad Gita 5.17 वेदान्तविज्ञानसुनिश्चितार्थाः | Mundakopanishad 3.2.6 सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते ।। Bhagavad Gita 4.33 PR 17 Jun 2016

item.title: Right Introspection - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji urges us to do the right kind of Introspection, constantly being aware of the mind. One must reflect whether it is overshadowed by either desire, hatred or fear. Only with the right kind of Introspection can the mind become absolutely free of desire, hatred or fear. Through interpersonal relationships, the mind comes out with its inadequacies, irregularities and defects. Being aware & attentive, one should go into the mind and find out if it is behaving properly or not and bring about the necessary correction. This is the introspection which can be done in any situation, anywhere and at any time. By introspection, the mind gets corrected and is treated beautifully. It can achieve any level of purity and goodness so that one can be happy. Every tiny fractional improvement will make the mind more joyous. Shlokas chanted in the Track: दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्र्च क्रोध: पारुष्यमेव च Bhagavad Gita 16.4 PR 17 Jan 2007

item.title: Spirituality - A Compulsive Pursuit to Enrich Your Inner Personality - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji discusses spirituality and meditation. The human body is an instrument in the hands of the mind and intelligence. Because our mind, intelligence and ego are spiritual, spirituality becomes an indispensable subject for everyone. Spirituality is the science and art of enriching, empowering, elevating and expanding one’s own mind and intelligence. The purpose of meditation, and its allied practices, is to understand the mind and intelligence and make it better, make the intelligence do its task of introspection, and through introspection set right all problems of the mind and find solutions for all. When introspection deals with the mind, with a view to dissolve the problems, then it becomes a sadhana. The highest form of human austerity is Truthful Introspection or infusional introspection. The purpose is to infuse into oneself qualities related to attitudes, responses and performance. One must have the quality of exclusiveness and dedication to every task that has to be performed. One must be loving, considerate and sacrificing for the sake of others. One must be free of the sense of doership, pride and ego. In the intelligence level, one must have clarity of understanding, wisdom. Spiritual pursuit is where one constantly strives to enrich the mind and intelligence. PR 23 Mar 2013

item.title: The Truth about the World - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In Yoga Vasistha Ramayana, sage Vasishtha says that the entire grossness and solidity that the world appears to present, is not a reality; it is only a myth. The wakefulness, along with the objective universe, disappears in sleep. The whole scenario is within the body. The solidity or grossness attributed to the world objects is not true. The subject-object distinctions totally disappear in sleep. Like they are disappearing in sleep, in wakefulness also when one starts spiritually introspecting over the truth of substances, there comes a time when the solidity and solid objects completely prove fallacious. Sage Vasistha says that in the transcendental level, there is neither the world nor the soul different from it; neither the body nor the soul different from it, neither the object nor the subject different from it. In the Supreme state, there is no creation and no dissolution; there is no bondage and no one striving for liberation. Shlokas chanted in the track: नासदासीन्नो सदासीत्तदानीं Rigveda 10.129.1 अन्यत्र धर्मादन्यत्राधर्मादन्यत्रास्मात्कृताकृतात्‌ । अन्यत्र भूताच्च भव्याच्च यत्तत्पश्यसि तद्वद ॥ Kathopanishad 1.2.14 न कश्चिज्जायते जीवः सम्भवोऽस्य न विद्यते । एतत्तदुत्तमं सत्यं यत्र किञ्चिन्न जायते ॥ Gaudapada Karika 3.1.48 न निरोधो न चोत्पत्तिर्न बद्धो न च साधकः । न मुमुक्षुर्न वै मुक्त इत्येषा परमार्थता ॥ Gaudapada Karika 2.1.32 PR 23 June 2018

item.title: Enquiry into the Self Alone is Devotion - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji says that Bhakti or devotion is a development in the inner personality of man. Devotion is something which rests completely in the mind. So, unless a devotee takes up introspection, devotion is not going to increase. Enquiry into the Self alone will give true shape to one’s devotion. One must enquire into the Self, understanding that God is no other than the synonym of the Self. The inner presence (which we refer to as ‘I’) is the unforgettable presence within. That presence is really God. A devotee cannot forget Him or get distanced from Him. A devotee will be able to understand this, provided he introspects on this using the mind. For this, the vicāra part has to be installed and preserved and strengthened. Shlokas chanted in the Track: मोक्षकारणसामग्र्यां भक्तिरेव गरीयसी । स्वस्वरूपानुसन्धानं भक्तिरित्यभिधीयते ।। ३१ ।। Vivekachudamani 31 वदन्ति तत्तत्त्वविदस्तत्त्वं यज्ज्ञानमद्वयम् । ब्रह्मेति परमात्मेति भगवानिति शब्द्यते ।। Srimad Bhagavatam 1.2.11 सुहृत् प्रेष्ठतमो नाथ आत्मा चायं शरीरिणाम् । Srimad Bhagavatam 11.8.35 PR 19 Sep 2015

item.title: The Three Kinds of Knowledge - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji, enlightens us about knowledge and the whole structure and treasure of knowledge. Existence and knowledge can be divided into two categories- Object knowledge (bodily and external) and Subject knowledge (mind and internal) There are three categories of knowledge–Pratyaksha (object knowledge gained by the senses), Paroksha (knowledge we get about the factors within the body. Here the mind and intelligence are used to infer things), Aparoksha (neither the senses nor the mind and intelligence work. This knowledge is called direct perception, direct realization!) A seeker must take to meditation and introspect using the mind and intelligence, until at last, he shuts his own mind and intelligence also. Then, whatever experience he will have, will be of the ‘I’. I’ is the subject in us. It is the subject, not merely in our individual personality, it is equally the subject of the entire universe. सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम् । yat-tad-buddhi-grāhyam-atīndriyam यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं तत: । यस्मिन्स्थितो न दु:खेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते ॥ yaṃ labdhvā cāparaṃ lābhaṃ manyate nādhikaṃ tata: yasmin-sthito na du:khena guruṇāpi vicālyate Bhagavad Gita 6.22 PR 19 May 2018

item.title: Vicara - The only Panacea for Suffering - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji says that Vichara is a process, a pursuit, a habit, a discipline, a powerful medicine, for the long-standing disease of worldliness. A seeker must spend sufficient time in doing Introspection. Everyone suffers by the impacts of the world. The focus of a seeker must be to make the impacts light and dissolve them. One has to imbue into the mind such thoughts, introspection and inputs, by dint of which, the impact from the world loses its effect. By activating Vichara, all the insufficiencies of the mind can be completely remedied, and a sense of abundance and affluence will start gracing the mind. By having the inner sufficiency, one can overwhelm all external situations. Shlokas chanted in the Track: दीर्घसंसाररोगस्य विचारो हि महौषधम् ।। (Yogavasishtha, Mumukshu-Vyavahāra-Prakaraṇam 14.2) PR 19 Sep 2006

item.title: Infuse Introspection into your Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji enlightens us about a conversation between King Sikhidhwaja and his wife Choodala in Yoga Vasishtha Ramayana. Choodala, a Self-Realized knower, believes that the spiritual goal can be attained by Vichara. Sikhidhvaja believes the goal is only attained by hard austerity and goes away for many years to the forest to perform austerities. After years, through a conversation, Choodala is able to bring home to him that external renunciation has nothing at all in terms of substance and purpose. Renunciation has to be inner and ultimately it has to be of one’s very mind, Swamiji condenses the dialogue and pronounces that mind is not gross or perceptible entity. It is experiential and expressive. By infusional introspection alone, the mind can be purified. So infusional, noble, spiritual, thoughts have to be infused in the mind to be purified. By Tattva Vichara alone, one can improve one’s spiritual, devotional and religious life. PR 19 May 2015

item.title: Truthful Introspection for Spiritual Progress - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The human body stops growing at the age of 21. The mind, intelligence and ego are the inner constituents which have to be cultivated and nourished throughout one’s life. The intelligence should do truthful introspection, introspection in which truthful elements are sought, employed and understood. The intelligence is the one factor which can influence the mind. The mind can be strengthened and properly guided by the intelligence. The intelligence must be given to inner introspection. The intelligence must introspect about Sukha, Duhkha, transitoriness and the immortal Presence ‘I’. PR 19 Apr 2018

item.title: Introspection is the Highest Level of Human Activity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha, in this Talk, speaks of the supremacy and excellence of the human intelligence and describes Truthful Introspection as the highest human activity. Vichara shapes the character, behavior and interactions of a human being. This art of thinking, where the intelligence is directed rightly through introspection alone, will not allow the mind to host unwanted thoughts and the ego will assert its imperishable dimension. It is only because of lack of introspection that one does not progress on the path of devotion and also does not gain spiritual fulfillment. It is only through the simple path of introspection, that the intelligence can delve into deep reflections about oneself, world, God and thus discover the source of Supreme joy and fulfillment. Swamiji states that it is only by the process of Truthful Introspection, Tattva Vichara, that the Vedas were composed, Maharishi Valmiki composed the Ramayana and Sage Vyasadeva the Mahabharatam. PR 22 Mar 2013

item.title: Turn every difficulty into Spiritual Enrichment | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji Nutan explains that every activity in our life can be transformed into Yoga by embracing the Yoga attitude. Even the deepest sorrow can be transformed to Yoga, as exemplified by Arjuna during the Kurukshetra war. Whenever we encounter danger or difficulty, a seeker should view it as an opportunity for growth. Without challenging situations, the mind cannot expand or ascend to higher dimensions to assimilate the experience. Swamiji further reveals that even the most daunting situations such as death or danger can turn into a celebration (utsava) in the presence of a Knower. Utsava, in its true essence, signifies the elevation and expansion of the mind, akin to the vastness of the sky.
