item.title: Outliving Religious Concepts | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: Nutan Swamiji explains that there is often confusion between religious and spiritual concepts among a vast majority of people. Not everyone will be able to understand the subtle truth, and many may not even care for it at all. Religion defines a general code to guide society and keep it on a moral track. It is based on beliefs such as the rebirth of the soul, heaven and hell, and the theory of karma. By asserting the existence of the Atma, which transcends the body, it provides an opportunity for people to inquire about what this Atma is, what is its nature and whether it goes anywhere, etc. However, when we delve into spirituality, we encounter difficulty in disentangling ourselves from these religious concepts, which makes it challenging to grasp subtle truths like the Atma and Brahman. Therefore, to comprehend these lofty and subtle spiritual truths, it is essential that we transcend religious concepts and embrace the higher levels of abstraction and truths proclaimed in the Upanishads.

item.title: The Importance of Introspection in Sadhana - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: How spirituality has to be pursued, its effects, why people do not pursue it are some of the questions Swamiji poses and answers in this beautiful talk. Vichaara is truthful introspection in which only the mind and intelligence are at work. In meditation all thoughts are dissolved but in vichara they are vibrant and we reflect upon them. Going into the mind, making the vichara intense and sharp, the intelligence perceives the supreme truth. Introspection on the Subject is a process where the mind and intelligence are alone involved to discover and verify what the mind, meditation, ego are and what is beyond all this! Swamiji urges seekers to get focused on Vichara and understand what happens when Vichara is done. Shlokas chanted in the Track: वासनाक्षयविज्ञानमनोनाशा महामते । समकालं चिराभ्यस्ता भवन्ति फलदा मुनेः ।। Yogavasishtaramayanam 5.92.17 विचारात्तीक्ष्णतामेत्य धीः पश्यति परं पदम् Yogavasishtaramayanam 2.14.2

item.title: The Importance of Introspection - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji says that the purpose of meditation is to purify and sublimate the mind. A seeker has to watch his mind and its interactions during the Pre and post meditation periods. The mind breeds desires and impurities like anger, fear, jealousy, possessiveness, ego, desires etc. One has to cultivate the right way of thinking and work on all the negative traits of the personality. A Sadhaka needs to introspect on the possibility of living in this world desire free and free of ego and possessiveness. Meditation is only a precursor to contentment and peace in the mind. It is our interactions and their effects on the mind pre and post meditation, that need to be introspected upon constantly. PR 16 Aug 2011

item.title: Knowledge Austerity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji exhorts seekers to take to the austerity of spending time devotionally, piously and with attunement with whatever he/she reads and try to understand it. Knowledge is a great austerity. It helps the seeker in bringing about sublimation, correction, fulfillment and refinement in his personality. Knowledge is the deepest faculty and constituent in the human personality. Mundakopanishad says that Knowledge austerity is the process by which the Brahman started growing and becoming matter, energy, force, senses, mind, intelligence and ego. Shlokas chanted in the Track: यदा पञ्चावतिष्ठन्ते ज्ञानानि मनसा सह । बुद्धिश्च न विचेष्टते तामाहुः परमां गतिम् ।। (Kathopanishad 2.3.10) यस्य ज्ञानमयं तपः (Mundakopanishad 1.1.9) तपसा चीयते ब्रह्म (Mundakopanishad 1.1.8)

item.title: Mantra Japa to Tackle the Mind II - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji says that it is the consciousness that has formulated our body, shaped our senses, imbued them with their respective powers and it is through these senses that the consciousness extends itself to become the infinite, endless world of variety. The first access we have to the consciousness is through the mind. Once a seeker understands that mind is the fulcrum in his Sadhana, the mind has to sublimate desire, hatred and fear which cause a lot of torment and trouble. How to access the mind? One has to take a mantra and start chanting it mentally. When one mentally chants a mantra, one is in the mind. After the mind arena, the seeker must progress to the intelligence arena where through a process of introspection he comes closer to the Self. Shlokas chanted in the Track: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिता: । बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागता: ।। Bhagavad Gita 4.10

item.title: Introspect to discover hindrances to saadhana - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this short message, Swamiji categorically states that a spiritual aspirant must introspect on whether his own Sadhana is wholesome. Introspection is an inner mental process which is most essential pursuit for a seeker of Truth. It is only by a process of constant introspection that a seeker can realize the Ultimate Truth. Manana (introspection) is the greatest worship, the greatest tapasya and the greatest yoga. Swamiji exhorts all seekers to take to the sadhana of introspection which alone makes the sadhana wholesome. Shlokas chanted in the Track: व्यवसायात्मिका बुध्दिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन । (Bhagavad Gita 2.41) बुध्दियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते । (Bhagavad Gita 2.50)

item.title: The Rare Intelligent One who Looks Inside - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Quoting an important verse from Kathopanishad, Swamiji says that we are born in this world with a set of organs which have only an outgoing capacity. So, man sees only the outside glory, the outside display which is fleeting. But a rare man understands that there is a power inside which animates and activates the body and the senses. He becomes introspective and through this pursuit realizes the Self within. Shlokas Chanted in the Track: पराञ्चि खानि व्यतृणत्स्वयम्भूस्तस्मात्पराङ्पश्यति नान्तरात्मन् । कश्चिद्धीरः प्रत्यगात्मानमैक्षदावृत्तचक्शुरमृतत्वमिच्छन् ॥ (Kathopanishad–2.1.1)

Shlokas Chanted in the Track: पराञ्चि खानि व्यतृणत्स्वयम्भूस्तस्मात्पराङ्पश्यति नान्तरात्मन् । कश्चिद्धीरः प्रत्यगात्मानमैक्षदावृत्तचक्शुरमृतत्वमिच्छन् ॥ (Kathopanishad–2.1.1)

item.title: Tattva Manana to Cultivate Qualities - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji, in this track, emphasizes the significance of Tattva-Manana in the life of a seeker. Tattva Manana means deliberation within oneself by engaging the mind and intelligence. It is the practice by which one cultivates desirable qualities and eliminates undesirable qualities. Introspection is the only way to understand one’s own inner personality. Swamiji stresses that our mind and intelligence are very resourceful. With their help we can transform every negative situation into a positive one. Shlokas Chanted in the Track: निन्दन्तु नीतिनिपुणा यदि वा स्तुवन्तु लक्ष्मीः समाविशतु गच्छतु वा यथेष्टम् | (Nitisatakam 84) तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया | उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिन: || (Bhagavad Gita 4.34)

item.title: Purity through Infusional Introspection - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In spirituality, the introspection is on the mind and intelligence themselves with a view to making them more and more qualitative, reformed, refined, and cultured, says Swamiji. Everyone should develop a habit of generating a dialogue between their intelligence and the mind with a view to infuse the benefits into the mind’s structure and the mind’s activities. A seeker must develop the habit of making the mind pure, noble and stable. One should become a knowledge-oriented person. Whatever we do, speak or think should be good. Swamiji exhorts everyone to take to infusional introspection which is an Introspection done with a view to infuse benefits into the mind. Shlokas chanted in the track: मातरीव परं यान्ति विषमाणि मृदूनि च । विश्वासमिह भूतानि सर्वाणि शमशालिनि ।। Yogavasishtha–Mumukshu Vyavahara Prakaranam–13.61 PR 06 May 2018

item.title: Importance of Manana or Introspection - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji, in this talk, states emphatically that every seeker must take to the habit of introspection. Whatever is read or heard, one must take to thinking deeply about it. Introspection can be about the nature of the world, our life and one’s own personality. Swamiji urges seekers to take verses from scriptures and introspect over them till the concept becomes clear in their own minds. He asks all seekers to understand the place and importance of Manana or introspection in their life of spiritual seeking. Shlokas chanted in the talk: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय । सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते ॥ Bhagavad Gita–2.48 यदृच्छालाभसंतुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः । समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते ॥ Bhagavad Gita–4.22

item.title: Thinking is the Sadhana - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji speaks about the importance of ‘thinking’ or ‘Introspection’ for a seeker. Repeated thinking over a concept is a great Sadhana which has a direct impact on the mind. Whenever you come across a concept, you keep revolving it in your mind until you become that. Swamiji stresses on the fact that a seeker misses the Truth only because he does not take well to the Sadhana of introspection. ‘Repeated thinking’ itself is Sadhana. Shlokas chanted in the track अत्र मां मार्गयन्त्यद्धा युक्ता हेतुभिरीश्वरम् । गृह्यमाणैर्गुणैर्लिङ्गैरग्राह्यमनुमानतः ॥ atra māṃ mārgayantyaddhā yuktā hetubhirīśvaram । gṛhyamāṇairguṇairliṅgairagrāhyamanumānataḥ ॥ Srimad Bhagavatam 11.7.23 पुरुषत्वे च मां धीराः साङ्ख्ययोगविशारदाः । आविस्तरां प्रपश्यन्ति सर्वशक्त्युपबृंहितम् ॥ puruṣatve ca māṃ dhīrāḥ sāṅkhyayogaviśāradāḥ āvistarāṃ prapaśyanti sarvaśaktyupabṛṃhitam Srimad Bhagavatam 11.7.21 PR 03 Sep 2018

item.title: Sharpen your Intelligence to Realize the Self - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji thunders, “Is there not a presence in your body? If there is a presence, why don’t you realize it? It is there – otherwise you would have been dead. You are not dead. So you are alive. What makes you alive? Something within the body. What is that? A thought arises, it subsides. Another thought arises. It is that source from which the emergence and subsidence, both take place, both are facilitated.” A great keenness of intelligence is required to fathom this truth and experience it. We need to sharpen our intelligence! Slokas chanted in the track स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात् ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 2.40) अयमात्मा नित्यसिद्धः प्रमाणे सति भासते । न देशं नापि वा कालं न शुद्धिं वाप्यपेक्षते ॥ (Vivekachudamani 531) PR 10 Jan 2012

item.title: The Significance of a Knowledge-based Vision - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: One must take to the jnana-drishti and judge matters on the basis of spiritual wisdom alone. Any experience is inner and subjective. Based on the fact that something is experienced in the sentient mind as a sentient note, is not the entire world simply Brahman, and not a matter-energy aggregate? Swamiji explains. Slokas chanted in the track दृष्टिं ज्ञानमयीं कृत्वा पश्येद्ब्रह्ममयं जगत् । सा दृष्टिः परमोदारा न नासाग्रावलोकिनी ॥ (Aparokshanubhutih 116) PR 12 Sep 2015

item.title: Viveka and Vairagya - The Twin pillars of Sadhana - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Repeated introspection over what we have read or heard from scriptures and great people will allow those values to get infused into our system. This is viveka, and then dispassion or vairagya develops over time. Slokas chanted in the track इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ । तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 3.34) भोगा न भुक्ता वयमेव भुक्ताः तपो न तप्तं वयमेव तप्ताः । कालो न यातो वयमेव याताः तृष्णा न जीर्णा वयमेव जीर्णाः ॥ (Vairagya Shatakam 7) PR 08 Sep 2015

item.title: Introspection for Self Realization - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: When by spiritual or philosophical introspection, the mental activities, mental functions, become subtler, feebler, lighter, slower, there comes a stage when there is cessation, and the whole introspectional process will come to be still. In the same manner, as the mind is active and vibrant now, it will become non-vibrant, buoyant and still. It is a state of a wonderful absorption. Slokas chanted in the track अतीव सूक्ष्मं परमात्मतत्त्वं न स्थूलदृष्ट्या प्रतिपत्तुमर्हति । समाधिनात्यन्तसुसूक्ष्मवृत्त्या ज्ञातव्यमार्यैरतिशुद्धबुद्धिभिः ॥ (Vivekachudamani 361) PR 03 Jun 2017

item.title: Infusional Introspection--Secret of Spiritual Sadhana - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji exhorts seekers to practice infusional introspection. When the intelligence does this introspection, the mind becomes stress-free and peaceful and the intelligence becomes more perceptive. This introspection is the secret of Spiritual Sadhana. The intelligence must be applied repeatedly on the subtlest of things–the Soul. PR 05 Feb 2016

item.title: Know The Self - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: For times immemorial, man has remained the same, with the same set of faculties. With the help of intelligence, one can plunge into the depth of one’s personality and identify the source of all experience. He will find altogether a single presence that gives rise to the thinker and the thought alike. PR 03 Jan 2018

item.title: Introspection itself leads to meditation - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The process of introspection, as it becomes briefer and briefer, lighter and lighter, shorter and shorter, until at last the very introspectional process will stop. Such introspection, when it is closely followed, it becomes meditation. Slokas chanted in the track यदा पञ्चावतिष्ठन्ते ज्ञानानि मनसा सह । बुद्धिश्च न विचेष्टते तामाहुः परमां गतिम् ॥ (Kathopanishad 2.3.10) PR 03 Jan 2016

item.title: Inner Purification through Introspection - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The purification of mind and intelligence is an internal process. When there is purification of the inner being through repeated contemplation, then one will be able to meditate upon the Truth. Slokas chanted in the track: न चक्षुषा गृह्यते नापि वाचा नान्यैर्देवैस्तपसा कर्मणा वा । ज्ञानप्रसादेन विशुद्धसत्त्वस्ततस्तु तं पश्यते निष्कलं ध्यायमानः ॥ (Mundakopanishad 3.1.8) PR 13 Jan 2018

item.title: Never fall from the Truth | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: For any seeker pursuing spirituality, it is imperative to introspect over and discern the Spiritual Truth, the presence 'I', which is different from the Pancha Bhutas, but yet which acts on them. At the same time observe and comprehend the external truth - the sun, moon and the world. Everything external is transitory. So, a seeker has to leave all of them and then identity with and become the 'I'. Swamiji says that it is a voyage in wisdom. One who is inspired by it should become an ascetic and totally depend on chance and providence. This knowledge is not intellectual, but experiential. It leads the seeker to a wonderful state of fulfilment.

item.title: Spiritual Sadhana | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Sadhana can be done in the physical level - going to a temple and praying in front of a deity; in the oral level - singing and chanting; and in the mental level - thinking about and repeating a mantra. But when it comes to Intelligential Sadhana it is very different from all of these. Here, the whole focus is on intense introspection to comprehend the ultimate Truth, the all-fold presence. Through this process of introspection, one has to gain necessary purity, serenity, humility and expanse of mind, and sharpness of intelligence to understand the subtle concepts. When the comprehension finally becomes personal and experiential, we become the Self, the Brahman and we have our inherence in Brahman.

item.title: Live the Truth | Words of Wisdom | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: Ma tells that as Spiritual Seekers, we must remind ourselves again and again that this life is for knowing our Real Identity and to realize it. We have to live this knowledge, every moment in our thoughts, speech and activities. The Self alopne is everywhere inside as well as outside. The feeling that there is nothing but the Self, should become ours.

item.title: Gurubhakthi and Earnestness in Sadhana | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji describes his sadhana in the pre-sannyasa life, his meeting with Baba and how the 'deeksha' (initiation) propelled his spiritual journey to its beautiful culmination. Swamiji had overwhelming measure of Gurubhakti and earnestness towards the sadhana. This was also complemented by an intense scriptural reading and exposure. Swamiji also enlightens us that meditation and the experience of meditation itself is not the be all and end all of spirituality. Spirituality has to be a complement to our life. The final goal is Knowledge, it is the Knowledge about the 'I'. It can only be experienced and felt. The truth that I am 'I' always is to be deeply comprehended.

item.title: Brahmavidya - The Strength and Inspiration of this Ashram - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji talks about the nature of Brahmavidya which this ashram stands for. He dwells in detail on the brahmavidya deeksha, its significance and effects. He also speaks about the Vedantic meditation that is to be followed after such a deeksha. सर्ववेदान्तसिद्धान्तगोचरं तमगोचरम् । गोविन्दं परमानन्दं सद्गुरुं प्रणतोऽस्म्यहम् ।। १ ।। Sarva-vedānta-siddhānta-gocharam tamagocharam Govindam paramānandam sadgurum pranato’smyaham (Vivekachūdamani 1) प्रत्यग्विमर्शातिशयेन पुंसां प्राचीनगन्धेषु पलायितेषु । प्रादुर्भवेत्काचिदजाड्यनिद्रा प्रपञ्चचिन्तां परिवर्जयन्ती ।। २४ ।। pratyagvimarśātiśayena puṁsāṁ prācīnagandheṣu palāyiteṣu | prādurbhavetkācidajāḍyanidrā prapañcacintāṁ parivarjayantī || 24|| (Yoga Taravali 24) PR 14 Dec 2015

item.title: From Knowing to becoming the Self | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji tells us that after getting initiation (Diksha) from his Gurudev, the only occupation for him was to be engrossed in the sadhana. To sit, think and identify with the Truth. The mind and intelligence are used to interact with the inner presence, contemplate on it, to bring more and more refinement and reformation to the mind and intelligence, until at last it identifies with the very Source of them.

item.title: Atma is to be 'Known' | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji enlightens us that it is Knowledge alone which will remain with us. This knowledge is the Self, transcending all known and unknown, all ideas and concepts. It is the presence denoted by the term ‘I’. This knowledge alone appeases all the agitations and turmoil caused by the world around. नान्तःप्रज्ञं न बहिष्प्रज्ञं नोभयतःप्रज्ञं न प्रज्ञानघनं न प्रज्ञं नाप्रज्ञम् । अदृष्टमव्यवहार्यमग्राह्यमलक्षणं अचिन्त्यमव्यपदेश्यमेकात्मप्रत्ययसारं प्रपञ्चोपशमं शान्तं शिवमद्वैतं चतुर्थं मन्यन्ते स आत्मा स विज्ञेयः ॥ nāntaḥprajñaṃ na bahiṣprajñaṃ nobhayataḥprajñaṃ na prajñānaghanaṃ na prajñaṃ nāprajñam । adṛṣṭamavyavahāryamagrāhyamalakṣaṇaṃ acintyamavyapadeśyamekātmapratyayasāraṃ prapañcopaśamaṃ śāntaṃ śivamadvaitaṃ caturthaṃ manyante sa ātmā sa vijñeyaḥ Mandukya Upanishad 7

item.title: Introspection to remove Impurity of Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: True introspection will lead to dispassion and non-expectation. Such desirelessness leads one to liberation. उत्पन्नपश्चात्तापस्य बुध्दिर्भवति यादृशी । तादृशी यदि पूर्वं स्यात्कस्य न स्यान्महोदयः ॥ मनो हि द्विविधं प्रोक्तं शुद्धं चाशुद्धमेव च । अशुद्धं कामसङ्कल्पं शुद्धं कामविवर्जितम् ॥ (Amritabindu Upanishad 1) PR 08 Apr 2017

item.title: The Process of Infusional Introspection - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Whatever is to be known is the substratum of all the perishable objects of the world, Swamiji says. Therefore the knowledge within the process of introspection itself. Slokas chanted in the track: विचारोत्थात्मविज्ञानं ज्ञानमंग विदुर्बुधाः । ज्ञेयं तस्यान्तरेवास्ति माधुर्यं पयसो यथा ॥ (Yoga Vasistha Ramayana 5.93.21) विचारय धिया सत्यं असत्यं हि परित्यज । (Laghu Yoga Vasistha 3.8.1) अबद्धो बद्ध इत्युक्त्वा किं मुधा परिशोचसि ॥ (Laghu Yoga Vasistha 3.8.2) अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे । गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 2.11) PR 02 Jun 2018

item.title: The Wholesome Spiritual Practice | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In his profound elucidation of Bhagavad Gita's verse 5.17, Poojya Swamiji expounds on the journey towards Truth. Upon receiving wisdom from the enlightened, our quest transcends mere awareness; it evolves into understanding, a deep internalization of Truth. Yet, this journey doesn't culminate in passive recognition; rather, it beckons us to embrace Truth ardently, allowing it to illuminate and shape our lives. As we nurture this flame of wisdom within, the impurities of our mind dissolve, and the constraints of our intellect loosen their grip. Through this inner metamorphosis, a radiant clarity pervades our being. Knowledge flows effortlessly, and we undergo a continual refinement in the crucible of wisdom. Ultimately, the crux lies in our willingness to honor the discernments of our intellect and be governed by it.

item.title: Who is a Jnani? | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji reveals to us that a person who does all his activities devoid of desires, expectations and imaginations, and who is rooted in the knowledge 'I am Consciousness', not the body - all his actions and their effects are burnt off by the Spiritual Wisdom. He becomes liberated from all shackles of worldiness. Such a person is considered a Jnani - an enlightened One.

item.description: In jñāna niṣṭa, our focus is sublimating, overcoming, outliving, transcending rāga dvesha bhaya. Every word that one utters will be with a view to overcome and sublimate these. item.title: The Eternal Relevance of Vedas and Epics - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji says that our Scriptures, Epics and Vedas are relevant for us even today. The Epics tell us about the values, ideals, principles, restraints and disciplines we should live by to make life successful, effective and fulfilling. The Bhagavad Gita discussion was for Arjuna to eschew grief, to overcome doubt, to imbibe boldness, to have the right comprehensive vision and inspiration to fight the war. Even today, Bhagavad Gita continues to inspire and guide seekers. PR 12 Jan 2016

item.title: The Message of Uddhava Gita - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Uddhava Gita, in the 11th Skandha of Srimad Bhagavatam, is the subject of discussion in this track. When Uddhava hears of Sri Krishna’s impending departure from the world, he confesses that he would be unable to bear separation from Krishna even for a second. In response, Sri Krishna imparts Knowledge which enables Uddhava to resolve the problems of his mind and get clarity and fulfilment. Swamiji says that our body is only a temporary tenure, embodiment. We will have to leave the body one day or the other. That leaving should be a fulfilled one and a fulfilling one. The entire Srimad Bhagavatam leads us to this understanding. Slokas chanted in the track: नाहं तवांघ्रिकमलं क्षणार्धमपि केशव । त्यक्तुं समुत्सहे नाथ स्वधाम नयमामपि ।। (Srimad Bhagavatam 11.6.43) PR 06 Mar 2012

item.title: Prose Vs Poetry in Spiritual Pursuit - II - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this audio, Poojya Swamiji speaks about the influence of Poetry in his life of seeking. It helped him remember the verses and reflect upon their meaning and significance. Poetic verses gave him the inspiration to reflect and contemplate on the Supreme Truth. Swamiji tells the listeners that the poetic verses stay in one’s memory and continue to inspire. He urges seekers to learn scriptural verses so that they become an operational force in the mind. Repeated repetition of the verses helps one cultivate qualities of the mind and intelligence. Shlokas chanted in this talk: वासनाक्षयविज्ञानमनोनाशा महामते । समकालं चिराभ्यस्ता भवन्ति फलदा मुने ।। (Yogavasishta Ramayanam, Upasama Prakaranam – 5.92.17) आनन्दं ब्रह्मणो विद्वान् । न बिभेति कुतश्चनेति । (Taittiriya Upanishad 2.9) चित्तस्य शुद्धये कर्म न तु वस्तूपलब्धये । वस्तुसिद्धिर्विचारेण न किंचित्कर्मकोटिभिः ।। (Vivekachudamani 11) कोऽहं कथमिदं जातं को वै कर्ताऽस्य विद्यते । उपादानं किमस्तीह विचारः सोऽयमीदृशः ॥ (Aparokshanubhutih 12) नित्यानित्यवस्तुविवेकः (Vivekachudamani 20) लब्ध्वा कथचिन्नरजन्म दुर्लभं तत्रापि पुंस्त्वं श्रुतिपारदर्शनम् । यस्त्वात्ममुक्तौ न यतेत मूढधीः स ह्यात्महा स्वं विनिहन्त्यसद्ग्रहात् ।। (Vivekachudamani 4) PR 09 Nov 2015

Shlokas chanted in this talk: वासनाक्षयविज्ञानमनोनाशा महामते । समकालं चिराभ्यस्ता भवन्ति फलदा मुने ।। (Yogavasishta Ramayanam, Upasama Prakaranam – 5.92.17) आनन्दं ब्रह्मणो विद्वान् । न बिभेति कुतश्चनेति । (Taittiriya Upanishad 2.9) चित्तस्य शुद्धये कर्म न तु वस्तूपलब्धये । वस्तुसिद्धिर्विचारेण न किंचित्कर्मकोटिभिः ।। (Vivekachudamani 11) कोऽहं कथमिदं जातं को वै कर्ताऽस्य विद्यते । उपादानं किमस्तीह विचारः सोऽयमीदृशः ॥ (Aparokshanubhutih 12) नित्यानित्यवस्तुविवेकः (Vivekachudamani 20) लब्ध्वा कथचिन्नरजन्म दुर्लभं तत्रापि पुंस्त्वं श्रुतिपारदर्शनम् । यस्त्वात्ममुक्तौ न यतेत मूढधीः स ह्यात्महा स्वं विनिहन्त्यसद्ग्रहात् ।। (Vivekachudamani 4) PR 09 Nov 2015

item.title: Finding a Way through this Complex Life - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The human mind is a complex medley of traits and qualities. The society is complex, and we have to live in it. There will be the gravest of conflicts and contradictions. Swamiji says that being the case, we cannot be held responsible for the present plight, but we are certainly responsible to handle it and go forward. What is the way? Slokas chanted in the track सञ्जयोऽहं महाराज नमस्ते भरतर्षभ (Mahabharata, Bheeshma Parva, 14.3) हतो भीष्म: शिखण्डिना (Mahabharata, Bheeshma Parva, 15.1) धर्मादधर्मो बलवान्सम्प्राप्त इति मे मतिः । (Mahabharata, Bheeshma Parva, 15.42) एतदार्येण कर्तव्यं कृच्छ्रास्वापत्सु सञ्जय । (Mahabharata, Bheeshma Parva, 15.62) दारुणः क्षत्रधर्मोऽयमृषिभिः सम्प्रदर्शितः । (Mahabharata, Bheeshma Parva, 15.60) धृतराष्ट्र उवाच – धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सव: । मामका: पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत संजय ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 1.1) PR 04 Jun 2013

item.title: The Relevance of Mahabharata - V - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Mahabharata, is the subject of discussion in this Track. There is nothing in Mahabharata which does not amply cover our complex and challenging life in this world. Swamiji discusses the episode where Draupadi is staked by Yudhishthira in the game of dice. Draupadi refused to accept the verdict that she was staked and argued how she could have been staked after Yudhishthira had already staked himself and lost and had become the slave of Duryodhana. Although she did not get any satisfactory answers, she stood her ground and stood firmly on her own freedom. PR 06 Jun 2013

item.title: Srimad Bhagavatam is a compendium of all aspects of human life - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Srimad Bhagavatam is a scripture that discusses not just spirituality but all aspects of human life including psychology, philosophy, character, behaviour, interactions, and others. It also talks about the birth, growth and fulfillment of human life. At one place, the architecture of Dwaraka is described in detail. Reading it, we get some knowledge of the life in those times as well. It is indeed a wonderful scripture. PR 10 Mar 2012

item.title: The Transformational Scriptures of India - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Our cultural heritage in the form of the scriptures contain accounts of impeccable human character and effective behaviour. They are intended to transform the personality of a reader and bring in, as Swamiji says, a characteral elegance, benahvioural majesty and interactional excellence into the personality. The Bhagavad Gita consists of words spoken by Krishna to raise an enervated warrior to his feet. Is it a religious gospel? No, it is a personality transforming scripture, Swamiji explains. PR 04 May 2017

item.description: Our epics like the Mahabharata have an eternal relevance because they contain incidents that that illustrate the negative emotions of the human mind, and by repeated reading thereof, we are also freed of them. Poojya Swamiji takes up the incidence of Draupadi vastra-harana to explain this point. PR 05 Jun 2013

item.title: Our scriptures envision the Supreme State - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The scriptures are eternal because they discuss something that is eternally relevant to man. They lead him to the supreme truth till he realizes it for himself. Thus, the scriptures are a fulfilling science. Slokas chanted in the track: अविज्ञाते परे तत्त्वे शास्त्राधीतिस्तु निष्फला । विज्ञातेऽपि परे तत्त्वे शास्त्राधीतिस्तु निष्फला ।। (Vivekachudamani 59) यदा पञ्चावतिष्ठन्ते ज्ञानानि मनसा सह । बुद्धिश्च न विचेष्टति तामाहुः परमां गतिम् ।। (Kathopanishad 2.3.10) प्रारब्धकर्मपरिकल्पितवासनाभिः संसारिवच्चरति भुक्तिषु मुक्तदेहः । सिद्धः स्वयं वसति साक्षिवदत्र तूष्णीं चक्रस्य मूलमिव कल्पविकल्पशून्यः ॥ (Vivekachudamani 551) PR 08 Feb 2016

item.title: The Profundity of our Scriptures - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna first assumes the position of a teacher and instructor, then as God himself and towards the end he says, God is seated in the heart. Seek refuge under Him. By the virtue of His blessings you will attain eternality and peace.” Then he again comes back to say, “I am the teacher and regard me as everything and I will give you liberation.” One needs to reflect upon this, and all our scriptures give plenty of opportunity for reflection. Slokas chanted in the track: यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे (Bhagavad Gita 2.7) ईश्वरः सर्वभूतानां हृदेशेऽर्जुन तिष्ठति । भ्रामयन्सर्वभूतानि यन्त्रारूढानि मायया ।। (Bhagavad Gita 18.61) तमेव शरणं गच्छ सर्वभावेन भारत । तत्प्रसादात्परां शान्तिं स्थानं प्राप्स्यसि शाश्वतम् ।। (Bhagavad Gita 18.62) PR 08 Aug 2015

item.title: Morality and Propriety in the Mahabharata - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Virtues should be such that they do not encourage and strengthen the vicious. They have to uphold dharma in the society. Mahabharata exposes all these subtleties through its complex narrative. Slokas chanted in the track: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच । धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः । मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 1.1) PR 03 Dec 2013

item.title: The Enormous Potential of our Mind to Triumph over Life's situations - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Life is full of conflicts, as evinced in our epics, the Ramayana and the Mahabharata. Yet any contradiction, any conflict, any persecution, any strife, anything whatsoever, we are bound to bear it and spirituality is meant for it, Poojya Swamiji says. Slokas chanted in the track: धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः । मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 1.1) अर्थस्य पुरुषो दासो दासस्तव अर्थो न कस्यचित् । इति सत्यं महाराज बद्धोऽस्म्य अर्थेन कौरवैः ।। (Mahabharata 6.41.36) PR 02 Jun 2013

item.title: Manana to Imbibe a Quality - I - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The Guru expects repeated manana from the disciple, says Swamiji. He urges us to incorporate the desirable and eliminate the undesirable qualities. Our inherent nature has both desirable and undesirable qualities. As we interact with the world, we recognize both and the shastras also help us understand this. Once we recognize the undesirable within us, we must work to eliminate them. The pursuit of life is to incorporate desirable and eliminate the undesirable. Swamiji asks us to spend sufficient mind hours on each quality, so that it becomes part of us. Mind should be applied so that the quality becomes part of us. 50 mind hours are required to imbibe any quality. The mind must be embossed with the quality and gradually it will be embellished with the quality.

item.title: Qualities of a Devotee - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: All the yoga that Krishna speaks of in Bhagavad Gita, involves mind and intelligence. This is true of the devotional field also. Devotion is centered in the mind. Pujas and ceremonies are not what we need to do. A seeker must offer this mind and intelligence to the Lord. He must make himself dear to the Lord by cultivating noble qualities. He must not have a sense of hatred, irritation or dislike towards anyone. He must develop an attitude of adjustment, affinity and appreciation with all the creatures of the universe. A seeker must pay attention to the quality of his mind. Bhagavad Gita urges a seeker to overcome dvesha and becomes friendly, amiable, sympathetic and courteous to all. Mentally, orally and monetarily one must be helpful to all. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च । निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी ।। सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः । मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः ।। Bhagavad Gita 12.13-14

item.title: Develop Qualities to Experience Spiritual Wisdom - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji says that it is very important for a seeker to cultivate qualities which will guide him forward in the spiritual path. When qualities start adorning the mind, spiritual wisdom becomes meaningful and relevant. The Sadhana is to develop qualities like Patience, forbearance, equalness in all situations, straightforwardness, innocence, tolerance, compassion etc. These qualities alone will enable one to experience the majesty, magnificence and ecstasy and serenity of spiritual wisdom. Shlokas chanted in the Track: मन्दमध्यमरूपापि वैराग्येण शमादिना । प्रसादेन गुरोः सेयं प्रवृद्धा सूयते फलम् ।। (Vivekachoodamani 28) ब्रह्मादिस्थावरान्तेषु वैराग्यं विषयेष्वनु । यथैव काकविष्ठायां वैराग्यं तद्धि निर्मलम् ।। Aparokshānubhūti 4

item.title: Qualities - Proximity to the Sadguru and Purity of Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this message, Swamiji speaks about the qualities mentioned in the thirteenth chapter. A seeker has to assess his own personality, its merits, demerits, the desirables and the undesirables, eliminating the undesirable, installing or incorporating the desirable. It is a sādhanā that is done in the sensory, oral, mental levels and the intelligence levels. A seeker must make sure that he practices external and internal purity. He should live, act, move, talk and think in such a manner that it has a purifying effect on himself. In the matter of understanding the self, gaining the necessary knowledge and realization, and becoming a jeevanmukta, the close association with the Sadguru is inevitable. A seeker must also have stability in his sādhanā, he must be unwavering, unshakeable, unassailable in his pursuit. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम् । आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः ।। (Bhagavad Gita 13.8)
item.dc:creator: Narayanashrama Tapovanam, An abode of Brahmavidya
item.itunes:summary: In this message, Swamiji speaks about the qualities mentioned in the thirteenth chapter. A seeker has to assess his own personality, its merits, demerits, the desirables and the undesirables, eliminating the undesirable, installing or incorporating the desirable. It is a sādhanā that is done in the sensory, oral, mental levels and the intelligence levels. A seeker must make sure that he practices external and internal purity. He should live, act, move, talk and think in such a manner that it has a purifying effect on himself. In the matter of understanding the self, gaining the necessary knowledge and realization, and becoming a jeevanmukta, the close association with the Sadguru is inevitable. A seeker must also have stability in his sādhanā, he must be unwavering, unshakeable, unassailable in his pursuit. Shlokas chanted in the Track: अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम् । आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः ।। (Bhagavad Gita 13.8)

item.title: Childhood of Poojya Swamiji - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji speaks about his own village and his own upbringing in which temples played a very large role. He speaks about how they would take their bath in the temple tank, sit in the mandapam and chant Vishnu Sahasranama and other hymns. Swamiji speaks about how there is a lot of gratefulness in his mind for his birthplace, his own upbringing and the atmosphere of the place. Shlokas chanted in the Track: न हि प्रमाणं जन्तूनां उत्तरक्षण जीवने. चरमश्वास वेलायां यत्कृत्यं तत् सदा कुरु

item.title: Excessive Attachment to Body makes us averse to Good Qualities - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Poojya Swamiji warns seekers against having excessive attachment to the body. Our body is completely grown by the age of 21. After that, the qualities which are to be developed by us are only in the inner personality. We can develop them till the end of our life. We are born in this world to imbibe good qualities, to be amiable and to be benevolent. Any good quality will make one dear to the others. One will be happy and contented in the hands of good qualities and the others around will also be happy to see our good qualities. Shlokas chanted in the Track: क्षणे क्षणे यन्नवतामुपैति तदेव रूपं रमणीयतायाः ॥

item.title: Sincerity and Straightforwardness - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji discusses the quality of sincerity saying that sincerity cannot be one-sided and selfish. You should be able to appreciate the quality of sincerity in others also. Sincerity has to be wholesome. Sincerity means having a lot of expanse, depth and loftiness to include others and embrace others. Shlokas Chanted in the Track: मुक्तिमिच्छसि चेत्तात विषयान् विषवत्त्यज। क्षमार्जवदयातोषसत्यं पीयूषवद्भज।। (Ashtāvakra Samhita 1.2)

item.title: Any Quality can be Cultivated by Mind Effort - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this track, Swamiji stresses that any quality can be cultivated by one’s own effort. One must keep the desired quality in mind and contemplate repeatedly on it and the benefits that it will give. Any quality is to be practiced and installed in the mind. A seeker must make sincere efforts to cultivate any desired quality. Shlokas Chanted in the Track: चीराणि किं पथि न सन्ति दिशन्ति भिक्षां नैवाङ्घ्रिपाः परभृतः सरितोऽप्यशुष्यन् । रुद्धा गुहाः किमजितोऽवति नोपसन्नान् कस्माद्भजन्ति कवयो धनदुर्मदान्धान् ॥ (Srimad Bhagavatam 2.2.5) PR 12 Jun 2015

item.title: What is Purity in every walk of life? - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Purity is an essential quality for a seeker, says Swamiji. A seeker should have a pure mind and intelligence. One must have a healthy, flexible and sensitive mind, so that it will be able to employ the body and the bodily parts efficiently in a very effective manner. Ultimately, the purity of the mind is when a mind not darkened with desire. Mind should also be free from possessiveness, hatred and ego. The intelligence becomes pure, when it is given to probing into the truth. Shlokas Chanted in the Track: विशुद्धसत्त्वस्य गुणाः प्रसादः स्वात्मानुभूतिः परमा प्रशान्तिः । तृप्तिः प्रहर्षः परमात्मनिष्ठा यया सदानन्दरसं समृच्छति ॥ (Vivekachudamani – 119) PR 12 Jul 2011

item.title: Guidance to the Young Minds -1 - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this audio, Swamiji addresses the youth and gives them guidance on improving their own personality. Swamiji emphasizes that it is very important for youth to keep a flexible and healthy body with the help of exercises. Just like nutrition and strength for the body, every young person will have to make the inner personality (mind, intelligence and heart) healthy, strong and flexible. Swamiji exhorts young people to pay special attention to their own character and behaviour and make sure they are excellent. PR 09 May 2008

item.title: Focus on Improving Character, Behavior and Interaction - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha

One has to work on all the three consistently throughout one’s life. It is important to observe one’s own character, behaviour and interactions closely and strive to bring about changes and improvements. Every time you should look for refinement, enrichment, enlightenment and elevation, says Swamiji. PR 09 Jan 2016

item.title: The Spiritual Law of Integrity - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji, in this talk, discusses the quality of integrity. Any quality of the mind and intelligence is a spiritual quality. So, integrity is a spiritual quality. A man of integrity is invariably sustained by spiritual laws which help him to succeed against all odds. item.title: Mental Transformation through Poetry - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: How is it that in ancient India, almost all treatises, whether in the field of science, mathematics, medicine, or literature, even dictionaries, were composed in poetry? Swamiji explains the benefits of reading poetry, how it re-organizes the mind and instills the qualities we want. One may not have the qualities initially, but chanting the poetry produces the joy equal to the attainment. Isn’t it a wonderful vehicle for transformation? Slokas chanted in the track सहनं सर्वदुःखानामप्रतीकारपूर्वकम् । चिन्ताविलापरहितं सा तितिक्षा निगद्यते ॥ (Vivekachudamani 24) PR 04 May 2018

item.description: That quality that enables us to distinguish between the changing and the changeless is viveka. This viveka sharpens our intelligence and makes our faculties subtler and more perceptive. It is an essential quality of a seeker. PR 13 Apr 2011

item.title: Cultivate Sattva Guna | Words of Wisdom | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: Ma tells us that we have to cultivate Sattva Guna as Rajo Guna and Tamo Guna are constantly trying to influence us and make us suffer. The way to cultivate Sattva Guna is to constantly introspect over the ephemeral nature of everything in this world. Nothing here can give us permanent happiness, rather they ultimately give us unhappiness. Also our mind is full of desires about various things and these desires make usrestless. So a wise person must cultivate sattva guna and remove all the desires.

item.title: Science Behind Temple And Prana Prathishta | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji enlightens us that there is a lot of science behind temples, installation of deity and deity worship. God is an all pervading presence, yet it is very difficult for most people to think or visualize his Omnipresence. So, the Priest who installs the idol, implores God to come and be present in the idol. He instills the force and power of Prana into the stone. The air is present everywhere, yet we can only breathe it. It does not immediately help relieve us of the heat or sweating of the body. But when we use a handfan to blow the air, we get a sooting effect. The air becomes functional. In the same manner, when the idol is consecrated, people will have a focus there and will be able to come and pray to God by looking at the idol. Shloka Chanted: सर्वत्रगोഽसि भगवन् किल यद्यपि त्वां आवाहयामि हि यथा व्यजनेन वायुम् | गूढो यथैव दहनो मथनादुपैति ह्यावाहितोഽपि हि तथा त्वमुपैषि चार्चाम् sarvatragoഽsi bhagavan kila yadyapi tvāṃ āvāhayāmi hi yathā vyajanena vāyum | gūḍho yathaiva dahano mathanādupaiti hyāvāhitoഽpi hi tathā tvamupaiṣi cārcām Tantrasamuchayam 6.64

item.title: All Religious Practices are to Strengthen the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: What is the purpose of religion? It is to instill spiritual values that will make the mind stronger and purer. With the help of examples from our epics, Poojya Swamiji explains the purpose of religious and spiritual practices. Slokas chanted in the track बुद्धिर्बलम् यशो धैर्यं निर्भयत्वमरिगताम् । अजाड्यं वाक्पटुत्वञ्च​ हनुमत्स्मरणात्भवेत्॥ (Subhashitam) PR 09 Dec 2016

item.title: The Need for Dispassion and Yearning for liberation - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In spirituality, what matters are dispassion and yearning for liberation. Even if one does not have dispassion, practice of introspection will bring it. When one understands that the whole world is fleeting and ephemeral, how can there be attraction towards it? The focus naturally lands on the substratum behind all the changes, and the yearning to know it grows. Slokas chanted in the track: मन्दमध्यमरूपापि वैराग्येण शमादिना । प्रसादेन गुरोः सेयं प्रवृद्धा सूयते फलम् ॥ (Vivekachudamani 28) अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति । नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 4.40) राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम् । प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम् ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 9.2) PR 03 May 2017

Slokas chanted in the track: मन्दमध्यमरूपापि वैराग्येण शमादिना । प्रसादेन गुरोः सेयं प्रवृद्धा सूयते फलम् ॥ (Vivekachudamani 28) अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति । नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 4.40) राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम् । प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम् ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 9.2) PR 03 May 2017

item.title: Qualities needed for Knowledge-pursuit - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: The existence of the world is depending upon us, the observer or the experiencer. This experientiality is the factor that we have to use in the whole of Vedantic study and pursuit. After hearing this, one should introspect or ruminate over whatever has been heard, until at last the knowledge becomes assimilated. This requires mind to be pure and endowed with virtues like truthfulness and sincerity. Slokas chanted in the track: एतज्ज्ञानमिति प्रोक्तमज्ञानं यदतोऽन्यथा ॥ (Bhagavad Gita 13.12) PR 03 May 2011

item.title: Develop Qualities of Mind and Intelligence - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Sri Krishna says that the kind of person who merges with Him is one who does everything for God, who thinks of God as supreme in his life, who is an exclusive devotee of God, and devoid of all attachments. Poojya Swamiji says that the entire sadhana is related to acquiring these qualities in the mind and intelligence by which we gain the true identity of ourselves. Slokas chanted in the track: (Timestamp: 00:02:11) मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्तः सङ्गवर्जितः । निर्वैरः सर्वभूतेषु यः स मामेति पाण्डव ।। mat-karma-kṛn-mat-paramo mad-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ | nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu yaḥ sa mām-eti pāṇḍava || (Bhagavad Gita 11.55) PR 06 July 2015

item.title: Understanding a Good Quality will automatically Generate love for it - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji explains what is meant by a quality and gives two definitions, one is an inherent constituent or definition of an object, and another is something that qualifies the object/person. A good quality strengthens the personality, makes it more functional. Is there any alternative but to love it, asks Swamiji. This fondness for the quality is what helps in cultivating the quality. item.title: Qualities of a Knower - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji explains the difference between pratyaksha (directly perceptible to the senses) and paroksha (inferential). Then he goes on to explain how we need to expand our mind so that we can embrace the entire world and not just the immediate family. With this expansion, the mind becomes pure, and the seeker starts gaining the qualities of a knower, a mahatma. That leads to the transcendental experience. Slokas chanted in the track: (Timestamp: 00:03:48) निरस्तरागा विनिरस्तभोगाः शान्ताः सुदान्ता यतयो महान्तः । विज्ञाय तत्त्वं परमेतदन्ते प्राप्ताः परां निर्वृतिमात्मयोगात् ॥ nirasta-rāgā vinirasta-bhogāh śāntāh sudāntā yatayo mahāntah । vijnāya tattvam parametad-ante prāptāh parām nirvṛtim-ātmayogāt ॥ PR 02 Feb 2017

item.title: Renunciation is of the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Bhagavad Gita speaks about Renunciation. Tyaga and Sannyasa are the main two subjects of the Bhagavad Gita. The questions thus arises as to how to accomplish this Tyaga and Sannyasa? How does it reflect in our Interactions? Can Interactional Sadhana accomplish it? The entire world is designed by God, preserved by God. We play no part in it. But we still feel a sense of doership and enjoyership. A seeker must completely abandon the feeling of doership, enjoyership and sufferership. When all the activities performed are renounced attitudinally by the mind, it becomes the yoga for the buddhi. A seeker must introspect about God who has created and preserved everything and wholesomely surrender to the Lord. Sri Krishna says: “Mentally renouncing all actions to Me (the Supreme), regarding Me as the Supreme, let your mind, resorting to Buddhi Yoga (anchoring the intelligence in the Inmost Reality), abide constantly in Me.” Shlokas chanted in the Track: चेतसा सर्वकर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्परः । बुद्धियोगमुपाश्रित्य मच्चित्तः सततं भव ॥ Bhagavad Gita 18.57 PR 23 Aug 2018

item.title: Every Exhortation in Bhagavad Gita relates to the Mind and Intelligence - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Discussing some verses from the Bhagavad Gita, Swamiji discusses Yoga in great depth and detail. We interact with the world and everything that follows is an outcome of interactions.The sense organs on their own do not have the power to function, without the guidance of the mind. So, our entire life is based on the mind. This mind can be acted upon only by the intelligence which has knowledge as the quest. Our entire life is an expression and extension of the mind, and all our problems are mind problems, which can be resolved by the intelligence alone. Our intelligence must generate whatever is needed to enrich and empower the mind consistently. This conjugation between mind and intelligence is what is termed as Yoga. Yoga is never external, nor sensory and physical. It is always inner, bearing upon the mind and intelligence. Krishna also discusses Bhakti as a Yoga, which is based upon the mind and intelligence. A true devotee is one who is able to remain contented and joyful always. Contentment and joy are created and generated by the mind. Swamiji points out, that, if joy is a creation of the mind, then we must make our mind generate as much joy as one wants. This is called Yoga. Surrender also is another aspect of devotion. A seeker must offer his mind and intelligence to the Guru or the Lord. So, all the exhortations of Sri Krishna are Sadhana relating to the mind and intelligence. Shlokas chanted in the Track: सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः । मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः ।। Bhagavad Gita 12.14 PR 25 Jul 2015

item.title: World Experiences are Only Mental Imprints - III - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji urges us to think about the propositions of saakara, niraraka and nischala, spending time to understand them. It is by this that we will be able to increase our devotion. Explaining a verse from Ashtavakra Samhita, Swamiji says that anything that has a shape or a form is to be considered as untrue, unreal. That which is devoid of shape is niścala, immovable, motionless. Only when one has spiritual instructions (Tattva Upadesha), one will not be born again. Swamiji urges seekers to introspect on this one verse repeatedly. Shlokas chanted in the Track: साकारमनृतं विद्धि निराकारं तु निश्चलम् । एतत्तत्वोपदेशेन न पुनर्भवसम्भवः ॥ Ashtavakra Samhita 1.18 PR 20 Jan 2016

item.title: Upanishadic solution for Social Strife | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: In this enlightening talk, Nutan Swamiji tells us that all strife we find in the society is due to our own selfishness, comptetition, jealousy etc. We think 'I' is a body limited personality. That 'I' is a ficticious 'I', we assume a certain image of ourselves. We have a bias and partiality in our vision. This constricted vision brings all strife in the society. But when we try to understand this 'I', looking within, we finally reach a state where there is nothing different from I. We find that the whole universe is floating in the I, sustained by the Consciousness. This experience is important in our life to remove all our misconceptions in a complete and wholesome manner.

item.title: The Greatest discovery of the World | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: We always think that something outside us will make us happy. But the truth is that nothing from outside can ever make us permanently happy. The ancient rishis of our land, discovered this fundamental truth and in their effort to discover the source of permanent happiness, they turned within, leaving everything else. They discovered that when everything was forgotten, including own personality, they were flooded with joy. They realized that happiness is the natural property of our inmost presence. Nutan Swamiji says, this is the greatest discovery in the world as with this, our insufficiency feeling is eliminated. The person becomes fulfilled and intelligence becomes satisfied.

item.title: The Kitchen Story | Words of Wisdom | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: Narrating an incident from her life, Ma enlightens us that all our unhappiness and misery is due to our desires and expectations. A seeker should completely remove the desires as it is a bondage. Liberation lies in elimination of desires.

item.title: Going beyond likes and dislikes | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: In this beautiful talk, Nutan Swamiji tells us that fulfilment in life will come only when we are able to go beyond our likes and dislikes. Swamiji narrates an incident in Ashram where Poojya Swamiji had an animated conversation with a group of village hooligans, which made a great impression on him and made him realize what it means to go beyond likes and dislikes. Later, Nutan Swamiji took up the Construction work in Ashram, much against his personal dislike. This is Spiritual life; life beyond likes and dislikes.

item.title: Treasure of Contentment | Words of Wisdom | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: Ma narrates a heart-touching story of an old beggar who came to the Ashram and her interaction with him. Ma says, there is a fountain of joy within us, if we go within and touch that, it will always be happiness. One who is contented with what he has, is the richest man! Sloka Chanted: न खिद्यते नो विषयैः प्रमोदते न सज्जते नापि विरज्यते च । स्वस्मिन्सदा क्रीडति नन्दति स्वयं निरन्तरानन्दरसेन तृप्तः॥ Vivekachudamani 536

item.title: Renunciation is Renouncing the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Through the conversation between Kumbha and the ascetic king Shikhidwaja, Swamiji explains what is ‘Renunciation’. He says Renunciation is of the mind – as everything is felt by the mind, experienced by the mind. The mind, being consciousness, has got infinite powers. By virtue of these powers, it produces the gross objects, preserves them and makes us experience them. Thus, everything is a mental creation – in the mind by the mind. It is such a mind that we have to renounce. Renouncing the mind means renouncing the ego, ‘I’ feeling. Ego is the seed from which the whole world tree is spreading forth. The mind has the power and potential to produce and unproduce anything. Throughout the wakefulness, it spreads, extends and becomes, but at the end of the day it folds up into sleep, where there is no world, no ego is there. The world rises in the mind and sets in the mind. All the thoughts arise in the mind and also get dissolved into the mind. We want to reach a state where the idea of a thought itself becomes a non-entity. The same mind which becomes doubtful, can be happy and clear. It is possible for us to use our discrimination to understand this wonderful Sadhana and be benefitted by it. PR 20 Jan 2015

item.title: Delve Into the Thought Process - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji speaks comprehensively about our Mind, its power and potential. We suffer from ignorance or delusion about the self and our mind. This Ignorance is what is to be removed by proper pursuit of knowledge, by probing into the mind and intelligence and by enquiring about the Self. What we need is a kind of mind in which all thoughts are always enlightening and informative and not affecting or agitating. By proper introspection, one must understand that mind and its thought are the same in substance. The thought is no different from the mind. One must be able to delve into the thought process, mind process and understand that there is only one Presence there. A seeker must meditate only to recognize this one presence, exhorts Swamiji. Shlokas chanted in the Track: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः । तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ।। Bhagavad Gita 5.16 PR 19 Jun 2016

item.title: World Experiences are Only Mental Imprints - II - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this audio, Swamiji says that the mind uses or employs the eyes to see the objects, to grasp them. At the grasping level, the mind is the source and cause. Then, after or in the grasping process, all the objects are imprinted by the mind itself. It is these imprints that one is experiencing. Once this is understood – there will be Nirapeksha (non-expectation) in the mind. One will think: “Can my mind desire its own imprints? If everything is mental and mind born and mind imprint, then what is there to be desired?” Nirvikarah (unchanging) – one will understand that the mind cannot be affected by its own imprint? This kind of reflection makes the mind cool, comfortable, and calm. Swamiji urges seekers to make the Buddhi deep and expansive. The only yearning in the mind must be to know the Self, one’s own real nature. Shlokas chanted in the Track: tvayā vyāptam-idam viśvam tvayi protam yathārthataḥ ।। Ashtavakra Gita 1.16 निरपेक्षो निर्विकारो निर्भरः शीतलाशयः । अगाधबुद्धिरक्षुब्धो भव चिन्मात्रवासनः ॥ Ashtavakra Gita 1.17 PR 19 Jan 2016

item.title: Affluence of the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji discusses Yogavasishtha Ramayana which tells us explicitly that the mind is an expression of the self. It is this mind that has to be tackled. Besides the mind, there is no other faculty a seeker has to focus his attention during the sadhana. Mind has a number of traits likes- dislikes, preference-prejudices, acceptance-rejection, desire-hatred, which only cause us distress. The mind has great potential. Atma has to be known and accessed by the mind itself. A seeker has to introduce desirable qualities in the mind. When the mind has the noble qualities, it gets transformed. Yoga Vasistha repeatedly stresses that one must be uniform with one’s own mind expressions. One must not prefer anything unduly, as a result of which one will dislike some other things. One must make the mind even and uniform in its responses, try to make it flexible and soft. So, one must treat the mind with a kind of universal evenness and fondness, treat it with a habit of tolerating, understanding and forbearing inputs from the world. If the mind becomes thinner, flexible, purer more and more sublime, one will start finding a contentment, fulfilment. The mind should be like an ocean which can withstand any waviness on the surface. By truthful introspection, the mind can have poise, flexibility, expansion, depth, loftiness, a sense of affluence and sufficiency. Mental affluence makes one the richest man in the world. One can directly make the mind affluent, resourceful and sufficient. PR 23 Sep 2007

item.title: Mind Is The Source Of Everything - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji clarifies that our mind is not a physical part of the body. It is associated with the body. Body is inert but mind and intelligence are not inert. Our eyes are the smallest organs in our body, but they can see infinite distances. The power and presence that have made the eyes, the hands, skull and brain, its potential and greatness is infinite. When we refer to the mind and intelligence, we refer to the potential of this PRESENCE. One never sees the world outside. It is the mind that takes the mental imprint, and that imprint is what we experience. So, in the experience of the world, the mind is crucial. The mind produces many thoughts, emotions, reactions, knowledge and doubts. All are mental products alone. Whatever the mind produces, they do not affect the mind. Every interaction produces only two impacts in the mind–pleasant-unpleasant, happiness-unhappiness. They are mind’s products and once they are assimilated by the mind, they cannot affect the mind. Swamiji urges everyone to feel the presence of the mind, far more than the world outside. One must think about the mind, probe into it more and more. The three states, Sleep, dream and wakefulness, are also a product of mind. PR 24 April 2016

item.title: Elevate Your Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji, draws our attention to one fundamental fact that entire life lies around oneself. Our ‘I’ expresses itself in the form of sensory activity, oral activity, mental, intellectual activity. But all these activities are designed and implemented by the inner personality. They are initiated by the mind, then implemented by the mind by employing the senses and it also concludes in our mind. The mind is the greatest treasure possessed by a human. One must cherish it and bring about improvement, refinement, expansion and liberality to the mind. Our human life is only meant to treat the mind and elevate it. One’s own mind and intelligence must be a very dependable friend and associate in life. For every problem sensed by the mind, the intelligence offers a solution. Shlokas chanted in the Track: उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत् । Bhagavad Gita 6.5 PR 22 Aug 2017

item.title: How to Understand the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji speaks about Sapta Bhumikas-the seven spiritual states of a seeker. It is not a physical growth, but a psycho-Intellectual growth of the seeker. Both the mind and intelligence are expressions of the Consciousness. The consciousness employs the senses and employing the senses, it perceives. The actual perception is in the mind, registration is in the mind, imprints are in the mind, the mind uses the senses to have its own imprint and these imprints are stored. So, though it is a sensory experience, and we call it direct, the experience itself is in the level of consciousness. After the mental imprints are made, mental role stops, and the intellectual role starts. The intelligence uses the mental data to think, to reason. As are the senses and sensory objects for the mind, so are the mental data, mental objects for the intelligence. But what functions as the intelligence is again consciousness. So, both the mental data and the intellectual finding data, are direct experiences. Shlokas chanted in the Track: बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम् । Bhagavad Gita 6.21 यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः । यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते ।। Bhagavad Gita 6.22 PR 19 May 2016

item.title: Potential of the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji continues discussing the potential of the mind and asks us to keep introspecting on the mind such that knowledge becomes the functional note in our personality. Manana is the key. The whole world is matter and energy and it is insentient. It is animated and activated by the Consciousness. Whether you call it the mind or the intelligence or the ego, substance-wise, it is the same cētana or consciousness. cētana or consciousness is not just the mind that is enclosed within the body. Mind is only a functional name. One aspect of the cētana’s function is called the mind. But as a substance the mind refers to the cētana itself. Such a mind gets affected by interactional impacts only when we cannot extend the knowledge that that the mind is infinite and potent to these impacts. We think the impacts are more powerful than the mind. They are actually ripples and waves and the mind is the ocean. A seeker must keep bringing the mind to the awareness and infusion of its potential whenever faced with agitations in interactions. Agitations are on the surface, and one must not get shaken by them. In reality, we are unaffected like the space, unshakeable like the mountains, and boundless like the ocean. Shlokas chanted in the Track: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन । बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् ॥ Bhagavad Gita 2.41

item.description: What is the most important factor in attaining the Spiritual Wisdom? Poojya Swamiji explains that it is the Shraddha - assiduos application of mind and intelligence, which helps attain the spiritual goal. Swamiji also briefly describes the three paths to attain it - dhyana yoga, sankhya yoga and karma yoga.

item.title: Realizing our eternal nature | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: Nutan Swamiji enlightens us that in reality there is no object at all. The world that we see and experience is appearing in the Consciousness. It is an apparent creation. Swamiji explains that this Knowledge is so wholesome that it wipes out all our clinging, likes and dislikes and enable us to serve everyone better; without ego, elation or depression.

item.title: How to make the knowledge our own? | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: Nutan Swamiji enlightens us that though we see this world as external to us, in our experience the world we see is what appears in the mind. So, subjectively, the world we perceive is made of Consciousness. When thoughts arise, we get disturbed, as we follow the thoughts. Though it is the Consciousness, which is taking the forms that we are experiencing, we get troubled by the differential notion. Swamiji says, it is our clinging to what we like and dislike, that creates hindrance in making the Knowledge our own.

item.title: Doing all activities as Yajna | Words of Wisdom | Swamini Ma Gurupriya
item.description: What is Yajna? Ma explains that every act that we do without delusional clinging to the results, becomes a Yajna. We should consider every work as given by God and do it in an excellent manner. There should not be any thought of personal gain, rather we should think of others and do benevolent acts. Ma also tells us that it is easier to renounce external objects but our thoughts, feeling and ideas are very difficult to renounce. As we do our actions with the attitude of Yajna, it results in spiritual gain, our mind imbibes good qualities and becomes calm and quiet thereby leading us towards the final goal of Self-realization.
item.dc:creator: Narayanashrama Tapovanam, An abode of Brahmavidya
item.itunes:summary: What is Yajna? Ma explains that every act that we do without delusional clinging to the results, becomes a Yajna. We should consider every work as given by God and do it in an excellent manner. There should not be any thought of personal gain, rather we should think of others and do benevolent acts. Ma also tells us that it is easier to renounce external objects but our thoughts, feeling and ideas are very difficult to renounce. As we do our actions with the attitude of Yajna, it results in spiritual gain, our mind imbibes good qualities and becomes calm and quiet thereby leading us towards the final goal of Self-realization.

item.title: Discerning the Real Atma | Words of Wisdom | Swami Nirviseshananda Tirtha
item.description: In the ancient times, the rishis used the 'arani' wood to generate fire for their rituals, by rubbing the two pieces of wood together. Nutan Swamiji explains that the fire is already hidden in the wood, only a proper effort is needed to manifest it. Similarly, the Self is what we are, but we are unable to manifest or feel It, because our body and mind are so much given to worldly and sensory delight. A Guru helps us in experiencing the Self within us. The sadhana or churning has to be done using the Knowledge, which is the greatest purifier. Using the Knowledge as the tool, we have to relieve our mind and buddhi, which is currently sold to raga dvesha.

item.title: Discovering the fire within | Words of Wisdom | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: We think we are the body limited personality, the world stands different from us and everyone here are individual Atma. But is that the truth? Using a mirror example, Poojya Swamiji explains what is original and reflected Consciousness and how the reflected consciousness is the Consciousness associated with and dependent on body. By discovering our Real identity, we transcend mortality and becomes immortal.

item.title: The World Floats in Your Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji says that spirituality is an experiential science. As perceivers, we give the objective reality to the world. The mind is subjective and all experiences are in this subjective sphere. We perceive the earth, water etc. Similarly, we know that we have a body. This knowledge emerges inwardly in the mind. Just as light illumines objects, the ‘I’ illumines the presence of the body and the presence of the world. Waking up, employing the senses and then perceiving the world – this perception is within the mental plane. The entire world is floating in our mind. In sleep this is confirmed repeatedly and the world is reduced to nothing. This knowledge makes a man full, like the ocean with vastness and depth. This knowledge can become a source of abundance and enrichment, concludes Swamiji. Shlokas chanted in the Track: यथा प्रकाशयाम्येको देहमेनं तथा जगत् । Ashtavakra Samhita 2.2 अतो मम जगत्सर्वमथवा न च किंचन ।। २.२ मुनिः प्रसन्नगम्भीरो दुर्विगाह्यो दुरत्ययः । अनन्तपारो ह्यक्षोभ्यः स्तिमितोद इवार्णवः ।। (Srimad Bhagavatam 11.8.5)

item.title: The Unfathomable Magnitude and Potential of the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji discusses the mind and reiterates the importance of introspection to understand its principles, processes, troubles and torments due to desires, hatred and other such emotions. Mind is not just a flimsy, weak existence, it is potent powerful and resourceful. It produces millions of thoughts and also emotions. Thoughts are produced and dissolved over and over again. This twin process continues as long as the body remains. Swamiji says that the mind is an expression of the soul. It has the power of creation and dissolution and thus it becomes virtually equal to God. Mind is an expression of an infinitely complex entity and once we understand it, all torments subside. Swamiji urges us to rely upon the mind, support the mind, ask the mind to dissolve the agitations it has, and it will do so readily and willingly. The mind has the power and potential to assimilate anything. A seeker only needs to understand it.

item.title: Probe into your Thoughts Through Meditation - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: In this talk, Swamiji discusses the benefit of a spiritual life and pursuit. Spirituality offers an inner gain, after attaining which, the spiritual seeker feels that there is nothing greater than that. The spiritual gain is felt in the sphere of the mind. The only way is to sit and delve into our minds. The gain belongs to the mind and intelligence. For some time daily, we must get into our mind and probe into its thoughts. Our mind is a wonderful source which can generate any number of thoughts, preserve them, and dissolve them too. Swamiji urges us to introspect on the workings of the mind and the origin of thoughts. One must sit in a place, close one’s eyes, be relaxed and get into the company of the mind and thoughts. Every thought must be evaluated preserved or disposed off only after we spend time on it. Through this process, the thinking will get filtered, reformed and refined. Mind is a gift, a treasure. We must spend time with it and recognize it. One must go into its nature, its qualities, by the process of meditation. One must plunge into the mind and become more familiar with our inner personality and this meditation leads to integration of the personality. Meditation can be attempted by everyone. It is the only way to get into our inner personality and bring about whatever enrichments and elevations we need and want. Shlokas chanted in the track: यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः । Bhagavad Gita 6.22

item.title: The Power and Potential of the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Activities and achievements in the world are traceable to the human mind. Sharing the examples of poets like Kalidasa. One has the power to transform the mind and intelligence. Even Panini worked on his mind and got clue to compose the sutras on Sanskrit grammar. Kalidasa transformed his own life and became a renowned Poet. Meera physically drank poison but there was no effect on her body. This is the power of mind over matter. Deeksha help a seeker to cling to a word, a sutra and invigorate the mind with it. This is one’s greatest austerity. Mind becomes active, convergence happens, and it gets more and more centric. Application by itself on itself is the only way. Shlokas chanted in the track: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन । Bhagavad Gita 2.41

item.title: Ramayana and Hindu Dharma - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji details how the Epics are not mere historical descriptions, but actually give through them, the values and inspiring lives of all the characters. Ramayana was composed by Sage Valmiki, who got transformed from the dacoit Ratnakara into a saint. Through the close association of the saints, he got free from all his sins. Through the poetic composition of the Ramayana, Sage Valmiki depicts the life of Maryada Purusha Shree Rama as well as all the characters in the kingdom of Ayodhya during the Treta Yuga. Swamiji speaks about the degradation of this lofty Dharma of our country today. There are malpractices in the temples and other religious worships. Various practices are polluting the minds and the society at large, instead of making people inculcate purity through the devotional practices. In this talk, Swamiji gives a clarion call not to fall a trap to these wrong doings in the name of devotion. Shlokas chanted in the Track: मा निषाद प्रतिष्ठां त्वमगमः शाश्वतीः समाः । यत् क्रौञ्चमिथुनादेकमवधीः काममोहितम् ।। वाल्मीकीरामायणम् बालकाण्डम् १.२.१५ को न्वस्मिन् साम्प्रतं लोके गुणवान् कश्च वीर्यवान् । (वाल्मीकीरामायणम् बालकाण्डम् १-१-२) PR 16 Apr 2016

item.title: Understanding the Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Spirituality is a mental pursuit. The only focus in on the mind, says Swamiji. Mind is either functional or non-functional and the entire sadhana is to deal with the functional mind and reach the non-functional state. From active to still. A thought-free state doesn’t stay forever, and we return to a thoughtful state. The goal is that the thoughtful state should not disturb us. We should be the same in both. First, we reach a thought-free fullness and thereafter we must progress to a state in which both the still and vibrant states are alike. Yoga Vasistha says: Lead the mind to samadhi. Ultimately overcome the state of samadhi and asamadhi and be equally at home with both. This is a lofty state where opulence and poverty do not delude us, strength and weakness cannot dislodge us and attainment and unattainment cannot subdue us. Shlokas chanted in the Track: यथा वासनया तज्ज्ञा विहरन्तीह कर्मसु । तां त्वं सत्त्वाभिधां विद्धि पुनर्जननवर्जिताम् ।। (Yogavasishtha 6.101.52) अथ चेतसि तत्त्वज्ञ स्पन्दास्पन्दौ त्वमेकताम् । नीत्वा तिष्ठ यथाकाममैक्यमागत्य शाश्वतम् ।। (Yogavasishtha 6.101.29)

item.title: Reasoning to Deduce that World is Illusory - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Swamiji asks us to evaluate why this world is considered to be mithya, even though everything around us seems to be solid. Our mind refuses to accept that it is a illusion unless we assess it from our intelligence level. Experiences are all inner. The subtle mind makes us experiences everything. All experiences are caused by the senses, which are activated by the mind. All gross objects derive their existence because the mind experiences them. All 3 dimensions are produced by the mind and that’s how we experience the gross objects. This entire world that we experience in our mind, can never be a factual reality but an imaginary entity. The mystery of the mind is a fact of our existence. Swamiji urges us all to think and ponder on this as he ends this wonderful talk.

item.title: Purity of Mind - Prabhatha Rashmih | Swami Bhoomananda Tirtha
item.description: Poojya Swamiji says that the mind is of 2 types – pure and impure. The same mind becomes pure and impure. The excessive attachment to the sensory objects of the world leading to sensory enjoyments conduces to bondage. The mind keeps struggling and cannot be contented and quiet. When the mind is free from their stranglehold, then it is said to be free. How to make the mind pure? A seeker must focus on removing the impurity and restoring purity. Contentment and joy as much as sorrow belong only to the mind, as they are experiences produced by the mind. Swamiji elaborates that the mind, intelligence and ego get purified by beautiful narrations like the Srimad Bhagavatam, listening to these holy stories, chanting the names of God. To the extent we are purified, to the same degree we are able to perceive the self. Shlokas chanted in the Track: मन एव मनुष्याणां कारणं बन्धमोक्षयोः । बन्धाय विषयासक्तं मुक्तं निर्विषयं स्मृतम् ।। Amritabindu Upanishad 2 मनो हि द्विविधं प्रोक्तं शुद्धं चाशुद्धमेव च । अशुद्धं कामसङ्कल्पं शुद्धं कामविवर्जितम् ।। Amritabindu Upanishad 1 क्षणार्धमपि केशव त्यक्तुं समुत्सहे नाथ Srimad Bhagavatam 11.6.43 यथा यथात्मा परिमृज्यतेऽसौ मत्पुण्यगाथाश्रवणाभिधानैः । तथा तथा पश्यति वस्तु सूक्ष्मं चक्षुर्यथैवाञ्जनसम्प्रयुक्तम् ।। Srimad Bhagavatam 11.14.26
